quotes.text: I've been on the 'I'm just gonna get through next week' loop for years—covering those feelings by doing work and trying to be busy.
quotes.fullText: I saw this tweet by Selma where it's a comic, where it's just like, I'm just gonna get through next week. I'm just gonna get through next week. And then it just becomes this ball of 'I'm just gonna get through next week.' And I feel I've been on that role for years now. It's a lot to do with my mom. And I've been covering those feelings of it just like doing a lot of work stuff and trying to be busy. But now that I actually have this space, it's so easy to fall into regular or old patterns. So I need this to be my actual focus project.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen naming the survival-mode pattern she's been in for years due to her mom's dementia. Recognizing that the freed-up space could easily be filled with old patterns of busyness unless she consciously protects it.

quotes.text: You want to take Wednesday off because if you take Friday off, you'll just fill it with work spillover. But Wednesday is early enough in the week that you'll take it.
quotes.fullText: If you try to do Friday, then you're just going to fill Friday with the things you didn't get done in your work, but Wednesday is so early in the week, you're going to take it because you have Thursday and Friday to do your other commitments. And then when Saturday comes around, like there's no choice, your kid is at home and you have to like go somewhere and do your work. But Wednesday is a magical time to take out if you want to work a little bit less.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen's practical insight about the psychology of time off. Friday is too tempting as a work buffer. Wednesday creates a real break because there's accountability to the rest of the week.

quotes.text: Instead of one canvas per trigger, you can make as many flows as you want on one canvas. That was pretty cool because related things should live on the same visual space.
quotes.fullText: I found one thing really cool: instead of having one canvas for each trigger endpoint, you can make as many flows you want on one canvas. And that was pretty cool because I have felt that pain point in both ConvertKit automations and in Make, where you're like, well, these things are related. So I would love to have them on the same visual canvas and then maybe even connect them to each other.
quotes.title: Energized, Building Data Trust & A Lovely Everyday Life
quotes.context: Queen finding a UX pattern in Bento she wishes existed in Make and ConvertKit: multiple related automation flows on a single visual canvas. Also mentions the ability to add sticky notes for documentation on the canvas.

quotes.text: Writing docs without a framework feels like shooting off little articles into the void — you need a plan that gives the whole thing coherence.
quotes.fullText: I realized I don't have a really good framework for how to make good documentation. Like I know how to use good documentation, but I haven't been in charge writing it. If it's a part of a bigger plan, it feels more worthwhile to write this down and be like, this is this type. This is a procedural documentation for X, and then we don't have the conceptual documentation, but we know at least that there should be conceptual documentation tied to this. Then it feels like you're working on something that will have a wholeness to it when it's done, instead of just shooting off little articles here and there.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen articulating why ad-hoc documentation feels demoralizing. The Docs for Developers book gave her categories (procedural, conceptual) that make individual pieces feel like they're building toward something complete.

quotes.text: By doing the product, that will be advertisement for the project. It's all about getting the first two customers and then nailing it.
quotes.fullText: I hope for Go Live where we stream founders that it's visible, so by virtue of doing the product, that will be kind of advertisement for that project. So I think it's all about getting the two first customers and then nailing it. If it doesn't really work the way we've expected, we'll have to maybe not do it. But I do think it will work really well if we can just get through the first two customers and do it. We can demonstrate it and by demonstrating it, people can see the product.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen identifying the self-marketing property of her Go Live service: each engagement creates visible proof for the next sale. The livestream IS the marketing — no separate promotional effort needed once it exists.

quotes.text: Even if you should be focusing 100%, maybe you can get your energy from a side quest.
quotes.fullText: I also believe probably for her that having those little side quests is giving her the energy she needs to keep at it with Whee, which is like a longer, more capital intensive type of a project. So I don't know. It's a little bit of both where it's like, even if you should be focusing 100%, maybe you can get your energy from a side quest.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen observing that the Whee founder also has side projects (coffee shop, bar) and hypothesizing they serve as energy sources for the main venture. Side quests aren't distractions -- they're fuel.

quotes.text: Oslo is hiring a few seniors instead of bunches of juniors — with AI tools, two seniors can do what a whole team used to do.
quotes.fullText: What they're looking for right now in Oslo at least is like a few seniors instead of like a bunch of juniors. Like usually the model was like getting in a lot of juniors and then like one or two seniors and like that was the team, but now they're more like, well, you know, with the tools we have, you could probably get the same job done with like two seniors alone.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen reporting what she's seeing in the Oslo job market: the traditional pyramid of many juniors + few seniors is inverting. Companies are hiring fewer, more experienced people and augmenting them with AI tools. This connects directly to the junior pipeline problem.

quotes.text: It's more challenging because of the physical aspects, but more immediate access to the people using the software.
quotes.fullText: It's a little bit more challenging because of the physical aspects. But then it's more immediate access to the people using the software. While in our SaaS world, they'll send a support request every now and then, but you don't get a thorough understanding of their daily pains.
quotes.title: Bike Inventory Puzzles, 2FA Edge Cases & Lemonade Stand Economics
quotes.context: Queen comparing the two sides of her work life: Whee (physical bikes, in-person feedback) versus Outseta (pure SaaS, remote users). The physical complexity adds friction but also brings the developer closer to real user pain.

quotes.text: I thought I should outsource things I'm not good at. But it turns out it can be nice outsourcing things you are good at — to free you up and work in parallel.
quotes.fullText: I also thought I should outsource things that I'm not that good at. But it turns out it can be nice outsourcing things you are good at. And just so you can work in parallel. It can get done in calendar time — I could do it, but calendar time would slide.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen flipping the common outsourcing advice. The conventional wisdom is to outsource weaknesses. But outsourcing strengths — tasks you could do well but that consume calendar time — unlocks parallel execution and faster shipping.

quotes.text: January is historically pretty high for us. I think our customers are more in that 'starting a business' phase, and somehow that is usually a New Year's resolution type of thing.
quotes.fullText: January is historically pretty high for us in terms of new customers coming in. It's often the first time they explore it - like some type of 'in the new year, I will start this business' and then they're testing out Outseta. I think our customers are more in that starting a business phase than your customers, and somehow that is usually a New Year's resolution type of thing.
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Explains predictable seasonal pattern in support volume - January spike, then easing. The pattern directly connects customer business lifecycle to support load.

quotes.text: Sometimes the business responds too fast with no-code because when you have to type it out, you have time to think about whether you should.
quotes.fullText: He was like, sometimes a little too fast. When you have to code, you know, when you have to type it out, you have that time where you're like, well, should we make this? It reminds me about all the ways this could break or screw things up. And did they need it? Is this actually the best path forward?
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen relaying the Xano power user's observation that no-code speed can be dangerous—coding's friction is also thinking time. The property manager said they sometimes shipped too fast because the tool removed the natural pause that writing code provides.

quotes.text: Put it out cheap with minimal photos and disclaimers, then iterate—the same MVP approach that works for software works for launching an Airbnb.
quotes.fullText: All of these years doing things on the internet has prepped us a little bit because all I was like, let's just make an ad. And he was like, yeah, we need photos, we need this and that. And he was like, let's just put two photos up in some description and just let's see. And then we've been slowly working on the listing. It's starting to be pretty good, but we already have three bookings. So what we did is put it out pretty cheap with minimal amount of photos and with disclaimers in the text being like, you know, there's a cat living here, the kitchen isn't done, it's a rustic property.
quotes.title: Trusting the MVP, Airbnb Launch & Next.js Rant
quotes.context: Queen describing how their internet business experience shaped their Airbnb launch strategy. Ola got the listing up in two days, then they iterated. Already had three bookings before the listing was polished.

quotes.text: Clerk lets you set up templates for different services and request differently formatted JWTs—you could click 'Supabase' and get a Supabase-compatible token.
quotes.fullText: Clerk has this approach where you can ask for a differently formatted JWT. So you can set up templates in their system for different services, and then you can add your signing key there. So when you log in with Clerk, you can say like, Clerk get Supabase access token. But then they kind of own it. They have these templates and you can essentially build out your own template in a no-code way where you drag in tokens and say what you want where.
quotes.title: Token Exchanges, Debugging Horror Stories & AI's Convincing Errors
quotes.context: Queen researching Clerk's approach to multi-service authentication. The template-based JWT exchange is an elegant pattern she's considering for Outseta's future—letting users visually configure how tokens map between services without writing code.

quotes.text: Coders want to code, but what you need are people who are more concerned about making the thing than coding the thing.
quotes.fullText: He said, it's really hard to find people because coders want to code. So you need to find people who are more like systems people or who are more concerned about making the thing than actually coding the thing. I think we've seen that shift in house building, where before you had to actually build a house. Now it's more about finding the correct modules to build a house.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen relaying the Xano power user's hiring insight: the no-code shift requires 'systems people' who care about outcomes over craft. The house-building analogy makes it vivid—modular construction needs different people than brick-laying.

quotes.text: I can't get to the videos I envision without making all the other videos first — it's code plus storytelling plus different scenes, not just a screen recording.
quotes.fullText: I can't get to the videos I want to make without making all the other videos. Like I need to make a lot of videos to get to the point where I can make the videos that I envision in my head that are like, yeah, it's code, but it's also storytelling and different scenes and it's more like engaging than just the screen and that's it.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen articulating the creative skill gap she's facing: her vision exceeds her current ability, and the only way to close the gap is volume. She sees developer content as potentially cinematic — code with storytelling and scenes — but knows she needs reps first.

quotes.text: Webflow has 700,000+ pages—it's a better market than chasing smaller, fragmented site builders.
quotes.fullText: I think leading with Webflow, it's like 700,000 pages or something at this, or like at this point, it's a better market than going after the smaller ones.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Market sizing: Webflow dominance (700k+ pages) makes it a focused, defensible beachhead. Resist the urge to add Squarespace, Framer, Card immediately—nail Webflow first.

quotes.text: Why don't I sell live streams? Developers want more video content but can't do it alone. On my streams, guests become their real selves instead of robotic.
quotes.fullText: I just love live streaming. And then I realized, why don't I sell live streams? Like for people? People want to do more video, people want to create more content, and having a live stream and then having that chopped up into 10 clips — most of our live streams can at least be 10 clips. That is something I know how to do now, and I just love it and I think I have the energy for it. And a lot of developers don't on their own, but usually when we get guests onto our live streams, they become a different — I guess they become more themselves. Like I've seen videos they've made, or I've seen talks they've made and a lot of them are very robotic. But then they come on stream with me and Ola and suddenly they're just relaxed. They kind of forget that they have to be this professional persona.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that her superpower is making people comfortable on camera. Developers who are stiff in solo videos become natural on her streams. She's packaging this into a service: biweekly streams + clip production = a client's entire content calendar.

quotes.text: Most of the issues are arising from the custom code while the no-code stuff is just running without any issues.
quotes.fullText: At this point, like most of the issues are arising for this custom code while the no-code stuff is just running without any issues, which I find super interesting.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen's observation at Whee: the Airtable-based no-code systems the COO built are running fine. The Next.js custom-coded customer portal is where all the bugs live. A counterintuitive finding that challenges the 'real database' advice.

quotes.text: I can feel these little bursts of energy, winds of energy that pass me, and I'm slowly trusting that I might get that creative energy and energy to execute back.
quotes.fullText: But I can like feel this like little bursts of energy or like like winds of energy that like passes me. And then like I have a couple of days where I'm like Oh I'm back to like actually being exhausted but like becoming more and more frequent and they're staying for longer. And I'm like slowly slowly like trusting that I might kind of get that like creative energy and the and just like the energy to execute things in the coming month.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen tracking her own recovery trajectory. The creative energy isn't back fully, but she's noticing the pattern of recovery—bursts getting longer and more frequent.

quotes.text: In Outseta you just change the price and people start being charged the new price. In Stripe you have to create new prices, migrate everyone, and use subscription schedules.
quotes.fullText: I realized how good Outseta is because in Outseta, I could have just gone in to all the plans and just changed the price and people would start being charged a new price for the plan that they're on. But in Stripe, you have to create a new price for every product and then manually, or with a script, move everybody from the old price to the new price. And we want to do this from December 1st, so in Stripe you have to use the subscription schedule feature.
quotes.title: Token Exchanges, Debugging Horror Stories & AI's Convincing Errors
quotes.context: Queen experiencing Stripe's price change pain firsthand while managing Wee's annual price increases, then appreciating how Outseta solves this natively. A lived-experience competitive advantage story she can tell authentically.

quotes.text: Making Framer a primary platform focus similar to Webflow—pushing the upgrade script button so users get latest Outseta configurations.
quotes.fullText: What the plugin does is like add the Outseta script to the page in addition to some other things. Um, so I want them to click the little upgrade script button so that they get like our latest, um, configurations for Framer.
quotes.title: New Year Gratitude & Framing Perception
quotes.context: Queen's strategic pivot to treat Framer as a core platform for Outseta integration, similar to the Webflow relationship. The plugin design focuses on keeping configurations current.

quotes.text: You need to take the decision to break away from yourself. Create automatic triggers like you do for social media scrolling.
quotes.fullText: I need to start having these if-this-then-that in my brain. I've started doing that for social media scrolling. As soon as I start noticing I'm scrolling and just looking around, I just have to get up and walk away from the desk. That's my only if-this-then-that. And that's been helpful. But at this time I wasn't really procrastinating doing other things. I just wasn't moving forward in my thought process. So I needed to manage some kind of if-this-then-that recipe in my head because you need to take these decisions away from yourself.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen proposing a systematic approach to breaks: pre-programmed behavioral triggers that force you to step away, because in the moment you'll always convince yourself to keep pushing.

quotes.text: When I couldn't sleep, things I'd been working on all day suddenly crystallized—drumming or horseback riding gives you that same outside perspective.
quotes.fullText: When I couldn't sleep last night, suddenly things I've been working on all day just crystallized. And I feel like drumming lessons or horseback riding or something where you kind of step outside fully and suddenly things just click into place.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen connecting the dots between stepping away from work (horseback riding, walks) and creative breakthroughs. The subconscious processes that happen when the conscious mind is fully engaged elsewhere.

quotes.text: The biggest productivity booster for me with AI is that you start on tasks you otherwise would procrastinate on.
quotes.fullText: You start on tasks that you otherwise would procrastinate on because I didn't think about that until today that I could just ask Jean Claude to write the emails, and then I did, and then I rewrote them and I got it done.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen identifying the most profound productivity shift AI brings: enabling her to tackle tasks she'd habitually procrastinate on. It's not about speed—it's about starting.

quotes.text: I often don't see the value in the things I enjoy. I sell the hard part because that's what I'd pay for, but the easy things are what people actually want from me.
quotes.fullText: I often don't see the value in the things that I enjoy. Like, I don't realize that not everybody can do the things because there are things that are easy to you. You're like, well, you know, anybody could just do that. Like, that's not what I can sell. So ended up creating products or creating things where it's like, I sell the hard part because that's what I think people would pay for. 'Cause that's what I would pay for, but they're hard for me.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen naming a key entrepreneurial blind spot: undervaluing skills that come naturally because they feel easy. She kept trying to sell difficult things (like edited video) instead of what she's naturally great at (live streaming, connecting).

quotes.text: When I'm on stream, I'm not checking Twitter, I'm not checking Slack, I'm not suddenly checking my phone. It really focuses me.
quotes.fullText: What is all good for me with streaming now is that sometimes it makes me not as focused because I can get frustrated when I can't get things to work, that I might have been faster to get to work if I wasn't on stream. But on the other hand, I'm not checking Twitter, I'm not checking Slack. I'm not suddenly checking my phone or like getting up to go grab a snack. Like it really focuses me.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen discovering that livestreaming is a double-edged focus tool: it slows her down on tough problems (can't think privately), but eliminates all the micro-distractions that normally destroy her deep work.

quotes.text: We need to understand how visual developers talk—do they say 'user data,' 'personalized data,' 'content'? The words they use determine if they'll find us.
quotes.fullText: As we talk, this is a pretty simple tool from a developer perspective where we're authenticating and authorizing a user and giving them the data they need. But what are the more junior developers or designer-developer types, how do they talk about it? Like, are they looking for user data? Are they looking for personalized data? Are they just looking for content? Getting all of that vocabulary down.
quotes.title: Unfocused, Redesigns & Row Level Security Pain
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that Galleon's marketing challenge isn't explaining the technology—it's speaking the language of visual developers who may not use terms like 'auth' or 'row-level security.' The user interviews are as much about vocabulary as validation.

quotes.text: Eight years in, customers have hundreds of discounts and segments—they need folders, search, pagination. The UI wasn't built for this scale.
quotes.fullText: Somebody was like, we have a lot of plans, we have a lot of discounts, we need folders. That's one of those things like you're eight years in. Your first customers are not gonna have a hundred discounts. They're gonna have two and then maybe five. But now some of the customers are getting bigger because we're more trusted and people have been using the software for maybe eight years.
quotes.title: Unfocused, Redesigns & Row Level Security Pain
quotes.context: Queen observing the natural scaling problem of long-running SaaS: early UI assumptions (few items, simple lists) break down as customers grow with the product over years. The ask for 'folders' signals a deeper issue about data density.

quotes.text: MCP servers can extract code snippets from docs to create better AI context without needing to hook up separate tools.
quotes.fullText: There's something called Context Seven that a lot of our users have been asking about. It's somebody who's created an MCP server of sorts where they go through your docs and extract code snippets from your docs, and then kind of makes better context for folks using AI. But you have to like hook up this Context Seven.
quotes.title: AI Context, MCP Servers, and Summer Travels
quotes.context: Queen discovering that Context Seven, an MCP server, automatically extracts relevant code snippets from documentation to provide better context for AI systems. This is a game-changer for companies with dense documentation.

quotes.text: A year is infinity in people's minds—they'll scramble this time next year, so the early migrations will help us dial in our systems.
quotes.fullText: A year, that's infinity in people's mind. They'll scramble this time next year. Hopefully we've had some really good migrations before that with people who are a little better at planning ahead. So that we have our systems dialed in and maybe even some really good demos from those earlier migrations so we can see what people really need and then create the templates and stuff.
quotes.title: Webflow Cuts Memberships, Let It Snow & Shipping the Imperfect Feature
quotes.context: Queen's strategic thinking about the Webflow migration timeline: use early adopters (planners) to test and refine the migration process, then be ready when the procrastinators scramble at month 11. Build from real migrations, not assumptions.

quotes.text: Electronics and bikes aren't made for maintenance because nobody makes money from it being maintainable.
quotes.fullText: They're not made for maintenance because nobody is making money off of it being made to maintain. But if you have a company where you're actually renting these bikes out, it is very beneficial if these bikes are made to maintenance and that you can maybe swap, you know, you don't have to use one specific part. Maybe you can choose between different suppliers for different parts.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Queen identifying a market misalignment: consumer products are designed for purchase appeal, not maintainability. Fleet operators have opposite incentives. This is the fundamental insight driving We's ambition to develop their own bike: when your business model is leasing, you need products designed for servicing, not for showroom appeal.

quotes.text: For me, tech was just one of the normal choices because my mom was a CTO. I want the next generation to feel like it's not a particularly brave or impossible choice.
quotes.fullText: My mom was a CTO at one point, or developer then CTO. So for me, like choosing tech was just like one of the normal choices. It didn't feel like a particularly brave choice, and that's what I wanted to feel like for the next generation. That all the little girls in my class know what I do and just feel like that's one of their choices. Like they don't have to, but it's not like it's impossible or it's not for them.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen articulating what visibility and role modeling means. Not that everyone should become a programmer, but that it should feel like an accessible choice because they've seen someone like them do it.

quotes.text: Start with the operations guy manually setting an estimated arrival time based on gut feeling, then automate the buffer once you have data.
quotes.fullText: At this point, what we're actually just doing is that the operations guy is manually setting an estimated arrival time. So he kind of looks at the resignation and then just makes a gut feeling: when will this bike be available for pickup? We'll start with that and then when you've done that for a while and we see how much buffer do we need, we can automate the buffer. So as soon as somebody resigns, we can say resignation date plus three weeks, and that's what we can promise our new customers.
quotes.title: Bike Inventory Puzzles, 2FA Edge Cases & Lemonade Stand Economics
quotes.context: Queen choosing the manual-first approach to bike availability estimation. Let the operations person build intuition and data before codifying it into an algorithm. Classic 'do things that don't scale' applied to physical inventory.

quotes.text: Sometimes you need to connect the dots looking back because as things are happening, you can't see the patterns.
quotes.fullText: Having these two kind of gigs that are both startups and both building products. Like I, well Outseta isn't a startup anymore. But I realized I'm probably never gonna be that person. But I am now embracing my ness and I am a fractional developer advocate for Outseta, which kind of came through that Gatsby work. And then we had one of the founders on this show interviewing them. So I feel like that kind of opportunity solidified a little bit through interviewing him on this show.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen tracing how her current Outseta role came through a chain of seemingly unrelated things: Gatsby expertise, podcast interviews, relationships built over time. Connecting dots backwards to see the spiral in action.

quotes.text: My brain was like, nope, we are productively procrastinating with this other thing instead of the higher priority Wix integration.
quotes.fullText: I was supposed to work on the Wix integration for Galleon, which is like a web flow thing. But what I've been working on is the Astro demo because that's what I wanted to do. So it's probably not like a higher priority. I think Wix is a higher priority because we have a lot of webflow people. But my brain was like, nope. We are productively procrastinating with this other thing instead.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen naming the phenomenon where her brain chooses the more interesting task (Astro) over the more strategically important one (Wix). At least it's still productive work, just misaligned with priorities.

quotes.text: Seeing these vibe-coded security disasters makes me realize I actually can do this. Maybe it's time I just realize I can.
quotes.fullText: It also just makes me in a way feel like it's time to just be bolder. Like, okay, let me, I mean, because I kind of feel like I don't have the authority to make like an authentication gateway. But then you look at some of these things and you're like, well, I wouldn't do that. So like, maybe it's not perfect, but it's definitely better than that. And you know, if they can, maybe it's time that I just realize I can. And then also know that I should ask for help and get like, you know, if this takes off, I would spend time and money to talk to people who are even better at this than me.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen working through her imposter syndrome by comparing her competence (which she knows is solid) to the actual security failures she's seeing. This is the moment where she gives herself permission to build the thing.

quotes.text: I get animation fatigue—everyone has to go through their circle of 'wow cool' to 'just give me the bare minimum.'
quotes.fullText: I get animation fatigue. I'm scrolling a page and I'm like, I just want to see the text. Give me the text. I don't want to see it fade in. I want to see my keywords so I can scroll past it because it's probably not what I need. But everyone has to go through their circle of, wow, cool to like, okay, just give me the bare minimum.
quotes.title: Webflow Cuts Memberships, Let It Snow & Shipping the Imperfect Feature
quotes.context: Queen naming 'animation fatigue' as a lifecycle stage every web professional goes through. Starting with excitement about what's possible, ending with wanting content without decoration. Connects to her broader identity arc of aging into functional minimalism.

quotes.text: If we go down next week, the worker they copied is still theirs on CloudFlare. Another developer could fix it. That alleviates the trust issue with being a new service.
quotes.fullText: From a customer perspective it's also super interesting because you are then not tied to our service. Like if we go down next week or next month, the worker you've copied would still be yours on CloudFlare. And you could have another developer go in and fix the code there. So it could also be a way to alleviate that trust issue with being a new service.
quotes.title: Physical Kanban, Worker MVPs & Sitting Out Scaling Problems
quotes.context: Queen reframing the copy-paste MVP as a trust feature. New products face the 'will they survive?' objection. By generating portable code instead of hosting it, customers keep the value even if Galleon disappears. The paid upgrade path: hosted deployment + saved configurations.

quotes.text: Building a reactive store where toggling a button updates everywhere on the page, matching React's patterns.
quotes.fullText: I've been working on creating a reactive kind of store so that if you toggle a button, it will update everywhere on the page in the way that we are used to with React. So now you can like click, click, click, click, click on the toggle button and it will only save like the last state.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: Building a reactive store for Framer users who expect React-like reactivity. This allows state changes to propagate automatically across the UI without managing subscriptions manually—a pattern React developers understand intuitively.

quotes.text: Agencies want client portals: log in with Outseta, land on Webflow, pull customer-specific data from Xano into a dashboard.
quotes.fullText: There's a lot of agencies that want to make client portals. So they log in with Outseta, they land on the Webflow page. And then on that Webflow page, they want to pull data from a database so they can have more specific data for that customer. And now that I have the Outseta-Xano script in place that could just be added to any Webflow site. I'll need to dig into how they usually do those kinds of integrations with pulling data from a backend. I've seen a lot of people do it. It's mostly grabbing data and then pushing it into a div with an ID.
quotes.title: Webflow Cuts Memberships, Let It Snow & Shipping the Imperfect Feature
quotes.context: Queen identifying the specific use case the Outseta-Xano-Webflow combo unlocks: agency-built client portals with authenticated dashboards. The technical pattern (inject data into a div by ID) is established in the Webflow community—she just needs to bridge it with the XO client.

quotes.text: We often forget to think on the onset: what kind of company will this idea need, and can we get away with doing it differently?
quotes.fullText: If you're new to the game, these are things you usually don't think about. It's like, oh, I have an idea, I think it fits, we see demand. And then you don't think about the, oh, what if we're successful, or what if this is for bigger companies? Like that is a totally different way of running a company. And that was not maybe what you wanted, which is fair, but it's something that we often forget to think about on the onset. Like, what kind of company will this idea need, and can we get away with doing it in a different way?
quotes.title: Shai Schechter on Exiting Right Message, Feeling Your Feelings & Life After SaaS
quotes.context: Queen reflecting on Shai's Right Message experience to extract a broader lesson: before building, ask what kind of company (sales model, team size, customer type) your product idea will require. Many founders only discover this mismatch years in.

quotes.text: I know this part of authentication and authorization pretty well now. It's owning up to that and being like, here's my product that will help you with that.
quotes.fullText: I've been thinking through it in many ways and was like, I know this part of authentication authorization, like I do know this pretty well now. But it's like owning up to that and being like, here's my product that will help you with that.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen naming her actual expertise rather than downplaying it. This is the shift from 'I'm not sure I'm qualified' to 'I actually know this domain well.'

quotes.text: When you have a full-time engineer, their time needs to be filled with engineering tasks. And engineers can always find engineering tasks.
quotes.fullText: I see that a little bit with Whee where they had a full-time consultant where they've started on projects that probably weren't a priority or weren't needed, but since they had somebody full-time, their time needed to be filled with engineering tasks. And an engineer can find engineering tasks.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen observing at Whee that having a full-time developer led to unnecessary engineering projects just to fill billable hours. A case for fractional technical roles -- pay for what you need, not what fills a calendar.

quotes.text: Tech people kept telling them to migrate to a proper database, but the real problem is the data model where customer, account, subscription, and bike are all muddled together.
quotes.fullText: I went in and I looked at their system and the issues they're having and I was like, this is not a database problem. It's a data model problem. It doesn't matter if we move on to a more professional or proper database because the problem is the model where the customer is also the account and the subscription and connected to a specific physical bike. So everything is muddled into the customer and the bike tables. If people then change phone number and then the login is on a phone number, so if you change your phone number, then you can't log in anymore and you can't change the subscription without losing access to the bike.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen's first major technical insight at Whee: previous tech advisors recommended migrating from Airtable to Postgres, but the real issue is entity modeling -- customer, account, subscription, and physical bike are all conflated. Moving databases would carry the same structural problem.

quotes.text: Claude writes really good articles from code demos—especially intros, outros, and key points. It's like having a workshop partner with instant feedback loops.
quotes.fullText: After writing the last one with Claude, I realized how bad mine are. If you have code, like if you have a code demo and you explain what you want the point of the article to be, Claude comes up with really good articles because the code is very simplified demo code. So it can extract what is the point of this demo. I've gotten pretty good at intros, but outros, I just never know what to write. And Claude just came up with key points. And it's not like I use it right off the bat 'cause it's never that good. But having that chat back and forth, it feels like working with, you know, when you workshop something. It's shorter calendar wise.
quotes.title: Gateway Goals, Sailing Countdown & Claude Writes Better Docs
quotes.context: Queen discovering that Claude excels at the parts of writing she struggles with: structure, key points, and especially outros. The back-and-forth revision process mirrors a real editorial workshop but compresses days of feedback cycles into minutes.

quotes.text: My mantra for fall was 'everyday life is going to be good' because between the two gigs we were okay financially.
quotes.fullText: This fall has been all about like calm. Every day life in the region is dig Vardag was like my mantra because we I had this check in with a business group I'm a part of and I just threw out whatever goal I had that I don't even remember and I was like The only thing that I'm gonna focus on now because between the two gigs outside and we like financially we were okay so my focus was just like Everyday life is going to be good.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen pivoting her business group goal from achievement to wellbeing. Shows a maturation in how she defines success.

quotes.text: I found a demo SaaS that uses the Supabase service key in the frontend—I could basically go in and delete everything in the demo.
quotes.fullText: I found a company that showed the demo of kind of how to do this and they said just use the Supabase service key because then you can just skip row-level security, which meant that I could basically go in and delete everything in this demo SaaS that they had created. So there's definitely like a need or a gap. Something here. And I also found that a guy who's been very vocal about vibe coding his whole SaaS basically had that happen. Someone went in and changed a lot of his customer's data. And he was like, I'm under attack. And most people who are more experienced are like, you're basically not really under attack, because this isn't, they haven't really had to do anything to figure this out.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen providing concrete evidence of the security risks in vibe-coded SaaS. This isn't theoretical—she's found real examples where public databases were exposed or attacked due to missing auth security.

quotes.text: Moving away from microservices and third-party dependencies gives you stability and control when SaaS providers deprecate features.
quotes.fullText: We're soon to have replaced the whole logged in pages or my, we, and even added new functionality around payments because it's, it's, it's gonna happen. Uh, and we won't have any say in that. Um, and yeah, and just like removing the services.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: Queen is moving away from microservices and third-party dependencies for Umwe's authentication layer. The reason: control. When you depend on a SaaS service (like Supabase), you're at their mercy for deprecations and breaking changes. A monolithic Laravel app on your own infrastructure gives her the stability and control she needs.

quotes.text: Framer's biggest pain point is the inability to use npm packages directly, forcing workarounds and making it harder to keep dependencies updated.
quotes.fullText: These are like the rough edges of framework, but I still think they're like on the right track. They just, you know, there needs to be something around distribution and, and hopefully we could just use known modules straight in NPM modules or NPM packages, but we can't, so you have to like package it all up together if you're gonna use state management libraries.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: A fundamental limitation that needs solving to unlock Framer's potential as a development platform.

quotes.text: When you get energized about something, you need to grab that energy and become a research sponge—but not too much of it or it gets scattered.
quotes.fullText: So I guess that also like feeds into that scattered feeling, which isn't necessarily bad because like I have to do research in multiple directions and kind of see what's out there. You know, make some hypothesis of what people would need and those kinds of things. And when kind of that comes over you and you're like ready to like dig into those things, it's also something to like grab that energy and start like digging into what is out there and looking at things and signing up for things and kind of just like being a sponge.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen reframing the scattered feeling as having a purpose: it's the research phase where you're gathering input before focusing down on execution.

quotes.text: I think that's how life should be at this point. A boring but good year is what you want at 40 plus.
quotes.fullText: You said like you had a good year like it was like a boring but good year. I also think that we're like 40 plus like that's how life should be at this point.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen reframing what success means in middle age. Uneventful stability is an achievement, not a failure.

quotes.text: Excited by traveling to teach real customers rather than pursuing growth—relationship-focused work over scale.
quotes.fullText: I wanna work more with like real people. Like real life and being able to maybe even like travel in Norway and like teach this historical society how to use our project. Like I don't even have to make money off of that part. It would just be fun to like go there and they pay for a training, but it doesn't have to like be a big money maker, but having like going out there meeting real people in like real settings. It's making me excited.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen explicitly pivoting from growth-focused to relationship-focused entrepreneurship. In-person teaching and customer support is the exciting part, not scaling.

quotes.text: Syncing data into Webflow collections is for public/static content; client-side fetching is for authenticated, private, dynamic data.
quotes.fullText: So it's not like Sano has a, I think they have a way where you can sync data into web, what's called Webflow collections. So that's a way also with Outseta, you can sync data from Airtable or you can sync Airtable to the collections, but that's kind of public data, right? It's, it's. It's not authentic. You just put everything in Webflow and then you build pages off of that.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Market clarity: Webflow collection syncing (Airtable into CMS) is mature but only works for public data. Galleon targets the different problem: private, authenticated, user-specific data requiring client-side fetching.

quotes.text: You can't promise exact delivery dates for physical inventory that depends on humans returning things on time—you need buffers and sliding windows.
quotes.fullText: People have resigned and we know they're supposed to deliver a bike by a certain date because that's when their resignation goes into effect. And this is the difference between physical systems and our regular SaaS—because in a regular SaaS you just shut off access. But we have to wait for them to come and deliver the bike. So we kind of have that date and we can say this bike will be available from that date plus a week because we need to do some work on it. But there are so many things that can happen, like the person could not show up.
quotes.title: Bike Inventory Puzzles, 2FA Edge Cases & Lemonade Stand Economics
quotes.context: Queen articulating the fundamental difference between digital SaaS (instant access revocation) and physical product businesses (humans have to physically return things). She's building inventory management for Whee's electric bike lease program.

quotes.text: My role is more support engineering than pure support - I also create integrations and work on technical problems that blur the line between support and engineering.
quotes.fullText: Yeah, so I guess what my role is more than like that initial role, it is support engineering and I also create integrations. Mia and I might start our own little association of email support engineers.
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen describes her own role evolution at Outseta - natural progression from pure support into technical problem-solving and integration work

quotes.text: Through Outseta's customers I can see that people are patching together no-code tools and will never need to go any further for their businesses.
quotes.fullText: I think even that has changed, because I can see through Outseta's customers that people are patching together these no-code tools. And will not need to go any further for their companies or their business ideas. I mean, if you're going to create UserList, at some point you'll need code. But like with the one company I was talking to this week, they're never going to need the type of scale that tech talks about.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen pushing back on Brian's framing that no-code is a stepping stone to 'real' code. For many Outseta customers, no-code IS the final destination. The business need simply doesn't grow beyond what patched-together tools can handle.

quotes.text: Location-specific audio guides for historical societies and museums solve discovery problems—learn about stories tied to physical places.
quotes.fullText: There's this old idea that we had came back to me. We did a lot of work, I think it's like seven years ago, eight years ago on audio guides that are location specific. So let's say you are a local historical society and you want more people to visit your town or like learn about your town. You make some kind of audio recordings about the history about certain buildings and you go to that building and you can listen to the story about that building.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen excavating an old idea that suddenly feels viable again. The concept serves local history institutions and museums with audio storytelling tied to physical locations.

quotes.text: The vision: become the default audio tour choice—'let me find an Umwe for this city' like Uber or Google.
quotes.fullText: I want it to be that come to city, you're always like, let me find an umwe for this city.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: Queen's aspiration is for Umwe to become the default choice for audio tours in any city—a brand-level goal similar to 'let me Uber' or 'let me Google it.' This shapes all product strategy decisions.

quotes.text: Sign up for lessons now for that future time, because otherwise you'll go into the 'next week' loop and never do it.
quotes.fullText: What you should do is sign up for lessons now for that time, because otherwise you're gonna go into the 'next week' loop. Like I do not have time to go horseback riding tomorrow. I do not have time, but I'm gonna do it because it's gonna give me more lovely everyday life.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen advising Benedikt (who wants drum lessons but says he's too busy) to commit now rather than waiting for a calm period that never comes. She's applying her own lesson from horse camp sign-up.

quotes.text: If your scale is 900 customers, a developer will build something heavily over-engineered. You could manually fix every database row.
quotes.fullText: With the one company I was talking to this week, they're never going to need the type of scale that tech talks about. Their customer base is based onto something physical that they need to go and acquire a physical thing to get another customer. So at this point there's 300 customers and when I was like, and they were like we needed to scale and I was like but what are we talking about, like in five years, if you've scaled, what are we talking about? They were like, well, you know, in three years we're hoping for 900 customers. Like, this is like, if you go to the developer and ask for scale, they are going to build something heavily over-engineered. If your scale is 900 customers, I could go in and manually fix your database with 900 customers, just update every freaking row manually.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen challenging the tech industry's obsession with scale through a real Outseta customer example. A business tied to physical acquisition will never need the scale developers assume. This directly validates the no-code/low-code approach for the majority of businesses.

quotes.text: AI chains together multiple simpler API calls automatically without needing explicit orchestration logic built in.
quotes.fullText: The AI is really good at figuring out which other tools it needs to make... I just need the change subscription logic... it'll actually often go and be like, oh, I need to figure out what the plans are.
quotes.title: Hungover & Excited About Location Audio
quotes.context: Queen discovering that when building an MCP server for changing subscription plans in Outseta, she needed far less business logic than expected. The AI model automatically chains together multiple simpler API calls (like getting plans, finding accounts) without explicit orchestration code.

quotes.text: I'm being very protective of both my time and what I commit to externally so I don't feel pressured to do more than I can handle.
quotes.fullText: I'm like very I'm being like very protective of both my time and and what I like commit to. Um like at least externally so that um I don't feel pressured to do more than than I can handle.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen setting boundaries proactively as she recovers. This is a learned skill from burnout—saying no externally before internal overcommitment happens.

quotes.text: I'm never going to be the slow and steady on one thing for years, but I circle back to things. Maybe I can do slow and steady in a spiral.
quotes.fullText: I'm 40 now and as I said, like I'm never gonna be the slow and steady on one thing for years at a time. But I do see that I circle back to things. So like I've been interested in no-code as a concept and I keep coming back to that, using it a little bit, like learning more about that and I'm like circling back and that works really well with the work I do with Outseta. And then I've also seen other things kind of coming back, like I've made back in the day some audio guide projects. Like now I kind of wanna look into that again. So things come back. So I'm trying to be mindful and thinking that maybe I can like, do slow and steady, but like in a little bit of a spiral that I can like spiral between these projects.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen articulating her core identity realization at 40: she is not built for single-focus persistence like Benedikt, but her circling pattern IS her version of slow and steady. This reframes what was previously self-criticism into a strategy.

quotes.text: In the ADHD community they call it body doubling. If there is a presence there, you just focus differently.
quotes.fullText: I think in the ADHD community, they call it body doubling. And it's this weird, weird, weird thing. If there is a presence there, you just focus differently. And at least I do that. And just trying to use that more to like ground myself and do things even in one and a half hour chunks.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen connecting her streaming and coworking experiences to the ADHD concept of body doubling. The mere presence of another person — even virtually — changes her focus quality. She's using this deliberately as a productivity strategy.

quotes.text: You log in with Outseta, exchange the token for a Xano token behind the scenes, and the user never knows two systems are involved.
quotes.fullText: You log in with Outseta and then you have to authenticate to Xano. So to do that, the concept is that you exchange the Outseta token for a Xano token. You send the Outseta token to Xano, you validate and do all that kind of stuff on Xano. And if it's a good token, you get a Xano token back that you can then use to authenticate with Xano in the same way as if you were using Xano authentication. So I made a little utility script that helps you to exchange. You kind of initialize the XO client and then that will just do this thing behind the scenes for you and give you an event when it's done.
quotes.title: Token Exchanges, Debugging Horror Stories & AI's Convincing Errors
quotes.context: Queen describing the technical architecture of the Outseta-Xano integration. The XO client abstracts the token exchange so non-technical users don't have to understand authentication flows. This is a recurring integration pattern she's solving once and packaging.

quotes.text: Command line users think they're faster, but when you measure them, they're not—coding feels faster than clicking, but it often isn't.
quotes.fullText: Come back to this research that I read in university, where people who use the command line a lot and not their mouse think they are faster. But when you measure them, they are not faster. Because you engage more of your head when you're doing it, so you feel more in flow. I feel like we're going to see that kind of disconnect with tools like Xano because I feel when I get frustrated in there because I can't do it exactly like I'm used to, it feels slower. But if I actually time it, I set up a webhook for Stripe in Make. I've done that a million times in code. And I have to admit, it was faster.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen citing university research about perceived vs. actual speed of command-line vs. mouse use, then applying it to the code vs. no-code debate. The cognitive engagement of coding creates a perception of speed that doesn't match reality. Her own Stripe webhook experience proves this—one hour with Make vs. never having done it that fast in code.

quotes.text: Create a framework where you add data attributes to visual components in Webflow to fetch and display API data without writing code.
quotes.fullText: So I started like making a little mini framework that lets you add data attributes for fetching and pushing data with just like a little script tag. So I'm making my own little framework. Don't all developers get to this point? So the idea then I was like, okay, if I can do this and connect Webflow then to Xano, that will be like the pitch, but it could basically be any API in a way that's much easier for the like less technical Webflow folks.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Core Galleon concept: bridge the gap between visual builders (Webflow) and backend APIs. Data attributes (gl-get, etc.) provide a visual-builder-friendly way to declare data fetching, inspired by tools like FinSuite and HTMX but adapted for Webflow's server-side rendering.

quotes.text: I sit next to the operations guy and get immediate feedback if this helps his life or not—that kind of feedback loop is pretty cool.
quotes.fullText: It's a lot of fun getting to work with the operations guy because I can be like, oh, I suggest we'll do it like this. And he is like, what if that or that. And then we can actually do some tests and I sit next to him and I get immediate feedback if this helps his life or not. And I find that that kind of feedback loop is pretty cool. Which is very different from our SaaS world where they'll send a support request every now and then, but you don't get a thorough understanding of their daily pains.
quotes.title: Bike Inventory Puzzles, 2FA Edge Cases & Lemonade Stand Economics
quotes.context: Queen contrasting the immediate, in-person feedback loop at Whee with the distant, asynchronous feedback of SaaS support tickets. The proximity to the user transforms the development experience.

quotes.text: Have well-known Framer template creators make templates with Outseta baked in—they keep their commissions, we get customers.
quotes.fullText: It could be a marketing play in Q2 or Q3 to have some of the well-known Framer template creators make templates either for our account, but maybe even on their accounts. Could you build a course platform template? You could even sell it and you can keep your Framer commission and your Outseta commission and everything, but then we get customers from people buying and cloning that template.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: Queen's future marketing strategy for Framer: instead of competing on design herself, partner with established template creators who already have distribution. Outseta functionality comes bundled with the template purchase. Win-win: creators keep all commissions, Outseta gets activation.

quotes.text: People are changing how they build APIs because AI can't understand non-standard conventions.
quotes.fullText: I've seen more and more people in our space being like, okay, you end up like changing the way you do things because you just can't get the AI to understand how it's done.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen observing a broader trend: API design itself is shifting to accommodate AI client expectations, not just human developer conventions. The AI adoption wave is forcing API naming and structure changes.

quotes.text: Technology is starting to become more of an annoyance than a benefit. Not everything has to be smart.
quotes.fullText: The farm that I go riding and this car didn't wanna start. I was like, do we need apps for everything really though? Technology is starting to become more of an annoyance than a benefit at this point.
quotes.title: Tech Situationship, Sailing Dreams & Script Versioning Strategy
quotes.context: Queen questioning smart-everything after a car-sharing app locked her out of a running car via a Bluetooth bug. A tech professional questioning whether app-mediated access to physical things is always an improvement.

quotes.text: We talk about data models on the podcast in a tech-agnostic way, but then offer one-click import into different database services — that's the sponsor value.
quotes.fullText: What we really wanna do in season two, if we can get database companies to join or even backend-as-a-service companies to join, where we go deeper into proven structures or models. My hope is that we can get sponsors — for instance Xano, or Appwrite or any of these — and have it be kind of there, like one-click into their service. But the information and what we're talking about on the podcast for that episode is generic or tech agnostic, but then we could have these one-click import into different services in addition, which would make it worthwhile for the sponsors.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen designing a sponsorship model for Data in the Wild that aligns sponsor value with audience value: tech-agnostic data model education on the podcast, platform-specific one-click imports as the monetization layer.

quotes.text: Sometimes jumping between things is you collecting little clues. Your mind gets to wander and after a week or two, suddenly direction emerges.
quotes.fullText: I have times where I'm more in that, like picking on a lot of different things and then often coming out of a period like that, things become very crystal clear. Or I have epiphanies that I wouldn't have if I sat and just coded on one feature. Sometimes jumping in between, it's like you're collecting little clues or your mind gets to wander and you look at different things and maybe you're a little bit on Twitter and suddenly you read an article about some new thing and then after like a week or two, suddenly it's like, oh, direction again.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen reframing Benedikt's unfocused state as normal and necessary. Drawing parallels to artistic creative processes where collection and wandering precede crystallization. The unfocused period IS the creative work, not a deviation from it.

quotes.text: Building SaaS requires distribution, resources, and planning. Even successful founders admit it's hard, and not everyone makes it work.
quotes.fullText: Like, you know, it's more like, you know, this is hard. Are you sure you wanna do it? Do you have the resources to do it? You know, do you have the distribution? Do you have like all of those things that you need to have in place and think about before, um, you do it?
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: MicroConf speakers weren't motivational; they were realistic. Building SaaS requires more than just a good idea—it requires distribution, resources, and planning. Even successful founders admit it's hard, and not everyone makes it work out long-term.

quotes.text: Cleaning horse stalls sounds yucky, but it's very meditative—you do a chore and you can see the thing happening.
quotes.fullText: You know, do the cleaning out of the stalls and all of that stuff that you need to do, which sounds super yucky, but it's very meditative. You stand there, you do a chore and you can see the thing happening and there's a relaxing horse there, and then you get to ride and look out at the beautiful fields.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen describing the therapeutic quality of physical, visible-progress work at the stables. A contrast to digital knowledge work where 'done' is always ambiguous.

quotes.text: Skip your calendar for year-in-review — scroll through Google Photos instead and you'll actually remember what made you happy.
quotes.fullText: They said go through a calendar and look at the highlights of the year. In my calendar there was like really nothing there and then I thought, oh, I should just go through my Google Photos. That is like a much better way. And then I just got really happy. I was like all these great people in my life and all the nice things I got to do with them.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen discovering a practical hack for the Year Compass exercise: photos capture emotional highlights that calendars miss entirely.

quotes.text: Mystery Dev is like mystery shopper but for developer tools — I use the product on camera, record my reactions, and deliver findings with video clips.
quotes.fullText: I was also floating around a different type of product that I called Mystery Dev. So I'm in the middle of one of those, and that is kind of like mystery shopper but for developer tools. So I just go in and I start using the product and I film myself as I do it. And I found a really good flow — I use StreamYard. I start using it and then I pause, then I write up my notes, and then I do a next session where I film and then I pause and then I write up my notes. And my plan was to then cut little sections to go with the notes.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen designing a new service offering: paid DX audits through real-time screen recording. StreamYard's pause feature enables a natural film-then-document flow. The deliverable is bulleted findings with embedded video clips of actual confusion points.

quotes.text: Success requires sustained effort and favorable circumstances. Many people along the way find it wasn't worth it anyway.
quotes.fullText: I think there's a lot of people along the way where it ended up not being worth it anyway. It got me thinking.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: Not every SaaS journey has a happy ending, even if people can afford to attend MicroConf. Success requires sustained effort and favorable circumstances. This insight discouraged her from pursuing side projects and encouraged focus on her main ventures.

quotes.text: Building your own company requires caring about marketing, sales, and operations—not just engineering.
quotes.fullText: I also think that people that choose to do that do, do that, like start their own company, um, or work on such a small team. Or in those kinds of businesses, you have to be interested in more than just the tech.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: MicroConf attendees are uniquely positioned to care about marketing, sales, operations, and more—not just engineering. This is different from large tech company employees who can specialize. This breadth of interest creates space for more honest conversations about the whole business.

quotes.text: Critical difference: Framer/Webflow use AI within stable visual environments as component-level tools. Lovable uses AI for everything and creates instability.
quotes.fullText: I feel like that makes it like. Versatility. And also they can, like, capitalize was the word. Uh, they can like capitalize on the AI of a wave without becoming like AI slop or like just ai. It's, it's, it's a stable like framer and web flow. The things you design, uh, on, on their canvases are super stable. And then you can like sprinkle in a little bit of AI instead of um. To create some of the components instead of having, you know, a lovable where nothing is stable and, you know, people are vibe coding and they were just gonna add a feature and suddenly their database is gone or their, yeah. So I kind of like this approach. Um, and I think people are using it, seem to like this approach a lot. 'cause they can like vibe, code with a little bit of guardrails.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen articulating a UX/safety philosophy: Framer and Webflow use AI as component-level tools within stable visual environments. Lovable and AI-first platforms make AI the foundation, creating instability. Guardrails matter.

quotes.text: Why do we feel guilty spending money on side projects that bring us joy while nobody bats an eye at expensive golf equipment?
quotes.fullText: One of the things I said is invest in tools and resources because why do we feel so guilty spending money on our side projects that give us joy while we don't feel it's wrong that somebody goes out and buys expensive ass golf equipment or horseback riding, you buy a horse and people are like, yes, you're not gonna make money off of that horse, but that's okay. But paying somebody to do something for your side project that brings you joy is suddenly something that we feel guilty about. Even just buying a domain, they cost what, 30 bucks a year? And we're like, oh, I bought another domain, I'm so bad.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Key insight from Queen's Laravel Live DK talk that resonated strongly with attendees. One person committed to paying for data entry on their side project after hearing this. Reframing side project spending as hobby investment rather than business waste.

quotes.text: Using data attributes to connect JavaScript to HTML is old school like Rails Stimulus, but it's the right pattern for visual builders.
quotes.fullText: It's super old school and that's why Webflow is so well, good for this because Webflow is, you know, separate pages, like, you know, every page is server side rendered or it's, it doesn't hydrate into any kind of like client side thing. So you can attach and you can be sure that when you reload the page, it's a new page.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Queen noting that Webflow's SSR architecture (server-side rendered pages, no client hydration) makes the data-attribute pattern particularly clean. Compare to Rails Stimulus. Old-school patterns are appropriate here.

quotes.text: Intentional community immersion shapes product direction authentically. Learn patterns, language, culture from ground level.
quotes.fullText: So I'm trying to like, pick up on the way they like to do things and the way they like to speak and, and try to showcase myself as somebody who kind of knows what they're doing. Not in design, but in functionality. Like, yeah. Um. So I'm trying to, so I'm like. Yes. I'm being like a little framer spy, like in the communities.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen describing intentional community immersion: she's learning how Framer designers speak, think, and operate. This shapes product direction and marketing authentically from ground level.

quotes.text: Lewis took the AI avatar technology from Geeky Medics and made it something other people can use for training—not specifically medical.
quotes.fullText: I think he's taken that technology and made it like something that other people can use for their training purposes, not specifically medical. So you can, he's extracted just like, what do we call that? Like when you take a part of your product and you make it a product, or a part of your stack and you make that a product. It's like a spinoff, I guess. So that's his kind of new venture on the side of, 'cause Geeky Medic is doing like really well.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: Lewis from Geeky Medics built AI avatar training for medical students (role-playing patient scenarios), then extracted it as a standalone product for any training use case. Queen sees this as a model: innovate within your successful product, then spin off the valuable component.

quotes.text: MCP servers are tools that orchestrate multiple API endpoints, enabling AI to perform complex workflows like changing subscription plans.
quotes.fullText: They call it a tool, and a tool is something that can call one or more API endpoints. I'm showing that you have to ask for the plans to be able to give a list of plans and then you can change, find the account, and then you can change the subscription from one plan to another. It's like a set of API calls.
quotes.title: AI Context, MCP Servers, and Summer Travels
quotes.context: Queen explaining MCP servers as coordination layers that sequence multiple API calls into coherent workflows. For Outseta, this means AI can orchestrate the steps needed to change a user's subscription plan without manual intervention.

quotes.text: If competitors aren't doing it yet, trying it and learning fast is low-risk/high-reward.
quotes.fullText: If you can just do it, won't your, you know, what will your competitors like? Do any of your competitors have one? We'll ask him. And he was like, no. And we was like, well, maybe you should make one then, you know, and just experiment.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: Queen's conversation with a technical founder about building an MCP server highlighted how technical founders can experiment quickly without committing resources. If competitors aren't doing it yet, trying it and learning fast is low-risk/high-reward.

quotes.text: Stripe has gotten so big and confusing—a million statuses, three ways to do everything, and you won't know which is right until you've experimented.
quotes.fullText: Stripe has gotten super confusing. It's gotten so big and it's necessary to cover all the things it needs to cover. But it's so much to wrap your head around. What webhook should you use? There's like a million statuses. Canceling but not canceled. And then there's three ways to do everything. And then finding active subscriptions—there's like three statuses of active and then overdue is kind of active because they still have a subscription. And when does overdue become canceled?
quotes.title: Jumping Ship, Summer Pivots & MRR Tied to Mood
quotes.context: Both Queen and Benedikt converging on the same insight: Stripe's complexity has outpaced its documentation. Edge cases can't be resolved by reading docs alone—you need to experiment with the simulator. This is exactly the kind of problem Outseta solves for its customers.

quotes.text: We're white-label so you don't see us. This could be a fun way to get people to take screenshots and share — look at my celebration of my first charge back.
quotes.fullText: We were talking about how to get our logo out there more, just how to get the name out there more and we don't have our logo on in emails and stuff like that. Like we are kind of white label so you don't see us. So I thought this could be a fun way to like get people to take screenshots and share, you know, look at my celebration of my first support ticket or my first charge back.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen solving a specific Outseta marketing problem: as a white-label platform, they have no natural brand visibility. Shareable milestone celebrations create organic moments where Outseta's name gets into the wild.

quotes.text: Framer's copy-paste workflow for overrides creates friction, but plugins can now create asset files to improve UX for discovering and using 60+ overrides.
quotes.fullText: Framer has this concept that you can like draw anything basically on the canvas and then you select the code override. It's like a logical component that can do anything, but still you have to copy paste code into file. These asset files. And now you can, a framer plugin can create an asset file. So that's what I'm gonna look at to like put our things in there.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: This reflects the tension between visual builders and code flexibility—asset files are a workaround for a UX problem.

quotes.text: People don't want different flows — they just want different designs. Give them theming and they'll stop building custom components.
quotes.fullText: We're also looking into that as a way to make it so that people don't wanna build their own custom components because it's much easier for them and us if they just use what we give them. And usually the only reason they wanna build it themselves is that they want the design to be different. It's usually not that they want the flow to be different, they just want the design to be different.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen's insight about what actually drives customers to build custom: it's visual, not functional. Theming solves the real problem and keeps users on the standard components.

quotes.text: None of them will become a unicorn. But that's what I realized: that's not the life I want.
quotes.fullText: They can all kind of go, like all feed a little bit off each other and none of them will then become a unicorn. But that's what I realized, like, that's not the life I want. Like I love this way of circling through and accepting that I think is gonna be the theme for this year.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen explicitly choosing the spiral life over unicorn ambition. The acceptance of this is new -- previously she felt guilty about not focusing. Now she sees the interconnections as the feature, not the bug.

quotes.text: Build a Webflow app that visually adds data attributes, turning the manual framework into point-and-click convenience.
quotes.fullText: We make the data attribute script, um, but we could also make an app that then lets you click on that component and then it adds the correct data attribute. So that would be like a next step, um, where first you will have to like manually do it, but then you can create a Webflow app that then lets you kind of, um, insert yourself into the editor.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Two-step distribution: (1) Script + manual data attributes, (2) Webflow app for visual UI. App gets discovered through Webflow's marketplace, providing organic discoverability and platform visibility.
