quotes.text: Using 'offset' to mean page number (not record offset) confuses AI clients and may require changing the API design.
quotes.fullText: Even I, like I've documented it... it doesn't even register the document... do we need to change the API?
quotes.title: Hungover & Excited About Location Audio
quotes.context: Queen grappling with a fundamental UX problem: their API uses 'offset' to mean page number (not record offset), which is counterintuitive and confuses AI clients. She's seeing this repeated in support tickets and wondering if the API design itself needs to change to accommodate AI usage patterns.

quotes.text: The first version could be a visual interface that generates a CloudFlare Worker—they copy-paste it into their account. No infrastructure for us, no trust barrier for them.
quotes.fullText: This made me think the first version of Galleon or our MVP could be a visual interface that generates these workers. For the use case where they can connect an authentication provider with a data provider and then configure row level security or some other kind of authorization in the interface. And then we can just spit out the worker and they can go and copy paste that worker into their CloudFlare account. 'Cause it seems like a lot of them already have CloudFlare accounts. In that way we don't have to sit on the secrets, we don't have to sit on the infrastructure for this first version.
quotes.title: Physical Kanban, Worker MVPs & Sitting Out Scaling Problems
quotes.context: Queen's clever MVP strategy for Galleon: generate code instead of hosting infrastructure. This sidesteps the trust problem (new service might go down), reduces costs (no servers), and meets users where they are (already have CloudFlare). The copy-paste model is a lead magnet, not the business.

quotes.text: Unlike HTMX which uses HTML templates, Webflow lets you build components visually and then our framework shows/hides them based on data states.
quotes.fullText: What I've been done in the Webflow world is that people actually put like HTML templates also into their Webflow site to then be able to use HTMX, but then you're not having that visual editor for those. So the difference with like my approach would be that you would create all of the components in Webflow and then we would you know hide them and then we would load the appropriate one. So it would be like gl loading for the loading state and then dl item or something for the item in an API results.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Critical differentiation: Galleon keeps the visual builder workflow intact. Designers don't need to write HTML templates—they build components in Webflow's UI, then data attributes control visibility/loading. It's HTMX-like logic but visual-builder-native.

quotes.text: I just want the feature to work—I can help them implement the utility things and not be responsible for whether it slides in or fades in.
quotes.fullText: I'm not that, I just want the feature to work. So I can help them implement the more utility things, like actually pulling data from Xano onto the site and then not having to be responsible for if they're sliding in or fading in or jumping up. I just want super simple websites that just let me do exactly what I need without that much swish.
quotes.title: Webflow Cuts Memberships, Let It Snow & Shipping the Imperfect Feature
quotes.context: Queen defining her role in the Outseta-Webflow ecosystem: she builds the boring utility plumbing while designers handle the visual polish. A conscious division of labor that plays to strengths—and implicitly an argument for wire-frame demos over design showcases.

quotes.text: Embedding the video on the demo itself felt so much easier than worrying about making it YouTube-worthy.
quotes.fullText: I could just upload it there. And I noticed that felt like so much easier than being like, oh, is this ready for YouTube? Where it gets a URL that never can be changed. You can archive it, but then the link will stop working. But embedding it on the demo itself, so the demo kind of becomes a tutorial. I just put it there and then now I'm having better ideas. I can record a new one and just put it there. And then when I think, this is actually a good video, I could put it on YouTube.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: Queen discovering that embedding video directly in Framer demos removes the pressure of YouTube permanence. The demo becomes its own tutorial, videos can be replaced freely, and only the best ones graduate to YouTube later.

quotes.text: AI coding feels like having a very confident intern who's wrong about 30% of the details but right about 70% of the patterns.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about AI development tools

quotes.text: They made it more secure, and we made it less secure by creating a shared tech account to work around their personal-only restrictions.
quotes.fullText: They made it more secure. We make it less secure by going back to, you know. We solved this by adding this tech user that then holds the credentials, which is basically, you know, they can then check off 'all credentials are personal.' But we ended up creating a shared account.
quotes.title: Thankful, Power Washing & Two-Factor Authentication
quotes.context: Queen identifying the security theater that happens when platforms enforce personal-only credentials: small teams create shared service accounts with passwords in 1Password, undermining the entire security model. The platform checks a compliance box while actual security degrades.

quotes.text: Having three similar plugins shows Framer users it's possible. More than just having one, people can check out different ones.
quotes.fullText: Having three versions or like three different plugins doing similar things, it also shows that it's possible, right? More than just having one and maybe people check out the different ones. We have a little bit of an advantage that we are more of a complete solution. And then we're also in a disadvantage because we haven't coded that much specifically for Framer.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen reframing competition as category validation. Three auth plugins in the marketplace shows Framer users that auth is a real need, which benefits everyone.

quotes.text: When you let users customize colors, you have to prevent them from choosing inaccessible combinations like dark purple on black.
quotes.fullText: Looking into how to make it so that they don't choose an inaccessible color combination, which is something I've seen people solve over and over again. But it's an important thing because people will choose weird combinations. Choosing dark purple on black background is not something we should at least call it out if they do that. Because it's not gonna be helpful for them.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen identifying a key UX challenge in the Outseta brand center: users will pick bad color combos, so the tool needs to flag accessibility issues proactively.

quotes.text: I created a mermaid diagram and took screenshots of notes, put that into cursor. I deployed the first version that's gonna be user tested.
quotes.fullText: I created a mermaid diagram of the flow and like going through all the states. And then I took some notes that he had made in TL draw. I screenshotted that. Um, and I put that into cursor and I have not been coding much, let's be honest. It's been testing and just telling it what it got wrong and also discussing that flow... So today I deployed the first version that's gonna be user tested.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Using visual diagrams as a shared language between humans and AI—Mermaid diagrams + screenshots + notes become the source of truth that the AI can reason about, creating a collaborative design process rather than dictation.

quotes.text: For new products, if AI guesses a pattern and there's no strong reason not to, just do it that way—your support load will thank you.
quotes.fullText: At least for like Galleon, I'm thinking, and this is like a new thing we have to think about, where I'm like, okay, I'll have to try to pretend to be a user of Galleon through AI and see kind of what patterns it guesses. Then if there isn't like a really good reason for not doing it that way, I should probably do it in that pattern. So that support will be easier because people will be using AI and asking it questions about Galleon, which is a new product that it doesn't really have a lot of info on, so it will guess how to use it.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen articulating a new DX principle: for new products, test what AI assumes about your API/events, then align with those assumptions unless there's a strong reason not to. AI's guesses become the de facto standard because every user will be AI-assisted.

quotes.text: Kick off an N8N process via webhook, enrich with AI, webhook back into Outseta, and wait for a field update to continue the workflow.
quotes.fullText: What you should do now is have a really cool demo where it kicks off some N8N process that does some AI stuff and a decision tree. You could have a webhook back into Outseta and then the next node would be wait until status is updated or a company is updated. If you could make a demo like that, then people will be like, yeah, Outseta is on the ball. I should go do that for Outseta as well. We could do a joint stream figuring out the N8N things.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen pitching a joint demo strategy with N8N: webhook out to trigger AI enrichment, webhook back to update the account, then continue the automation. The same demo could work for both Outseta and UserList. Shows how webhook nodes unlock the AI business operations ecosystem that's congregating around N8N.

quotes.text: Marketing should lead with specific integrations (Xano + Webflow), not generic 'fetch any API.' Users will discover generality themselves.
quotes.fullText: Because often I find things that I find easy, I'm like, nobody wants to pay for that. And then it's like marketing wise, like that's what people are asking. They want Xano data in Webflow. They want super based data in Webflow. And then kind of just showing them how to do that and not be like, Oh, you could fetch anything and put it in your Webflow site where it's very, like try to be very specific with the brand names. And then they can recognize that, Oh, I could put any URL in there.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Distribution wisdom: don't sell 'generic API fetching.' Sell 'Xano + Webflow' and 'Superbase + Webflow.' Once they see the pattern works, they'll realize they can use any API. Specificity leads to understanding.

quotes.text: We just sign up and if we have to email someone, we're like 'I'm not buying this if I have to talk to you.' You bring that bias when you try to sell your own thing.
quotes.fullText: Whenever we buy, we just go, we sign up and if we have to email someone or call, we're like, I'm not buying this if I have to talk to you. You want to go in there, get it done. And you kind of bring with you that bias when you try to sell your own thing. Because that's how you enjoy being sold to, but for others it's different.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen naming a blind spot for self-serve SaaS founders: they project their own purchasing preferences (no-touch, self-serve) onto all customers. But many buyers need human interaction before committing, and treating that as a nuisance loses sales.

quotes.text: I'm setting up a product ladder: streaming host, mystery dev (I use your tool and tell you how it goes), and standard video creation to pay the bills.
quotes.fullText: So I'm trying to set up a little bit of a product ladder with different DevRel services. So it's streaming host and then something I call mystery dev, which is like a mystery shopper. You book me and I'll use your tool, the document you already have and I'll tell you how it goes. And then I think I'll need to pay the bills, which is straight up video creation. There's a lot of people who want video creation of the standard sort until the AI is good enough.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen architecting a services business with three tiers. The 'mystery dev' concept (like mystery shopper for developer tools) is particularly creative — she uses your tool with only your existing docs and reports back on the experience. The video creation tier explicitly acknowledges it's temporary until AI catches up.

quotes.text: AI as a multiplier for keeping tech simple—allowing small teams to maintain straightforward, well-tested solutions rather than building complexity.
quotes.fullText: I've noticed that our product, like the tech side of our product is so simple, like we're not making a dev tool, right? We're just using tech to create a website that people can log in and order a bike—like this is very well tested and common use cases of web technology. Um, so I've noticed that, like getting better at using AI and having it work in parallel... will be super valuable for Bike because we don't live off of the tech, but we need it to serve. And if the AI can make good enough software for that, you know, we can level up a little bit and also get over to a more—even if it's AI—I want to use it to just have like a simpler setup that I've talked about, like simpler tech that is robust and will just like chug along.
quotes.title: New Year Gratitude & Framing Perception
quotes.context: Queen positioning AI not as a tool for complexity, but for maintaining simplicity. The goal is robust, well-tested tech that doesn't require constant attention—AI helps teams stay lean while keeping systems healthy.

quotes.text: The moment you think you've figured out developer experience is exactly when your users discover seventeen edge cases you never considered.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about DX complexity

quotes.text: If you have it scheduled on your calendar, you're gonna talk to me and we're gonna livestream it. There's no procrastination — you just have to show up.
quotes.fullText: When am I gonna write this blog post? And you know, there's always a million things happening in a startup, but if you have it scheduled on your calendar, you're gonna talk to me and we're gonna livestream it. You know, there might not be that many in the audience, but you kind of have promised your community that you will show up. So it's like there's no procrastination. You just have to show up and we'll go live and we'll make it fun and then we'll create good content from that without your involvement, or you can be as involved as you want.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen identifying the deeper value proposition of her livestream service: it's a commitment device. The scheduled stream eliminates the procrastination loop that keeps founders from doing marketing.

quotes.text: Instead of trying to sell edited videos, which is hard for me, let's just sell live streaming. And our first customer comes from a listener.
quotes.fullText: Realizing that we love live streaming so much and realizing that having guests on has worked really well, we're like, well, instead of trying to sell video edited videos, which is like hard for me, let's just sell live streaming. And it's like a record. And that's what we are testing out now on the side is live streaming and building together with other people. And then let that be marketing assets for those people. And our first customer comes from a listener.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen and Ola turning live streaming from a hobby into a paid service. The pivot from selling edited video (hard, didn't enjoy) to selling live build-with-us sessions (easy, energizing). First customer from the podcast itself.

quotes.text: We're moving into a time where life is going to happen to the maintainers of our critical open source dependencies.
quotes.fullText: I'm thinking like, you know, with my experience with my mom who got Alzheimer's when she was in her fifties, how do we make sure that a lot of these libraries, that are like the keys held by somebody who might die or get Alzheimer's or get illnesses that make it so that this is not their priority and not even their priority to figure out how to hand things over. We're moving into a time in open source, in addition to the politics, where life is going to happen to a lot of these libraries and dependencies.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen connecting her personal experience with her mother's Alzheimer's to a broader infrastructure concern: the first generation of open source maintainers are aging into their forties and fifties, where statistically health crises become more likely. The 'little brick holding up a whole project' meme is becoming more real.

quotes.text: When Webflow launches Webflow Cloud, we write tutorials for it and put Galleon Gateway at the bottom—riding their marketing push for free.
quotes.fullText: We could just take all of the things I've ever made and make an article that is how to do this on Webflow Cloud when people are googling for Webflow Cloud stuff. And then we could do in the bottom, you know, you can make a serverless function on Webflow Cloud, you can do all this filtering. And then it's like, if you want to just visually configure this, use Galleon Gateway. And take that playbook from Pierre of Scraping Bee where he really explains how you can do this on your own, but let us handle it instead.
quotes.title: Gateway Goals, Sailing Countdown & Claude Writes Better Docs
quotes.context: Queen applying Pierre's Scraping Bee content strategy to Galleon: write genuine tutorials for the manual approach, then offer the product as the easier alternative. Timing it with Webflow Cloud's launch steals organic traffic from their marketing spend.

quotes.text: Show up three or five times in one week instead of every other week. By the end of the week the person will have gotten used to it and we can get really good clips.
quotes.fullText: Instead of saying you have to show up once every other week, we could say show up three times in one week. Or if you really wanna go for it, five times in one week. Because then you kind of get over it — I would assume the first one will be a little awkward, the second one again, and then by the end of the week the person will have gotten used to it and we can get some really good clips. Maybe it's better to just power through, then it's like a project for them and they're done, but then we can create six to eight weeks of content for them.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen iterating on her Go Live service format in real time. The insight: anxiety compounds over two-week gaps but dissolves through repetition in a single week. Reframing livestreaming from an ongoing commitment to a bounded project.

quotes.text: Maybe ask them on our show as a low-key version where it's not for their audience — they can get a feel for it and see if it's something for them.
quotes.fullText: What I was thinking is maybe ask them on the show and have a low-key version where it's not like for their audience, but it's just like they're coming on our show and then they can get a feel for it and see if it's something for them. Like a little dry run.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen solving the sales objection for Go Live: prospects want to stream but have anxiety about it. Rather than pushing harder, she designs a low-stakes on-ramp — appear on Slow & Steady first as a trial. The idea came from talking through the problem on air.

quotes.text: Being able to be creative without expectations is something lost for adults and increasingly for kids. Things don't have to become a finished something to have value.
quotes.fullText: I think the creative, being able to be creative without expectations is something that is lost not just for us grownups, but also more and more for the kids. Where it's like it has to become a finished something for it to be of value.
quotes.title: Shai Schechter on Exiting Right Message, Feeling Your Feelings & Life After SaaS
quotes.context: Queen connecting Shai's productivity guilt to a broader cultural problem: the expectation that everything must be completed and productive to have value. She catches her own father imposing this on her daughter's drawing and pushes back.

quotes.text: Repeatable annual content asset. A snow plugin is niche, delightful, and instantly remixable across builders.
quotes.fullText: It's soon Christmas. We gotta make it snow on everybody's websites. And last year I took my Gatsby let it snow plugin and I made it into a, script tag version so you can just pop it into the head of any website builder and it will snow on your website from November 15th. If you don't change any of the defaults. Um, and I was like, okay, I should just make socials on this every year.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen describing a repeatable annual content asset: the 'let it snow' plugin is niche, delightful, instantly remixable across builders, and creates reliable seasonal engagement every year.

quotes.text: My mom was a CTO and she always started with a physical wall—nail the process first, then digitize it. Changing digital tools takes too much time when you're still figuring out what works.
quotes.fullText: That's something I learned from my mom who was a CTO and she always did this when she came in and cleaned up development teams and their processes to get them to ship. She would always start with a physical wall because then to get everybody on the same page. She was like, no, we're not gonna put this into any digital system until we've nailed down a process. 'Cause changing a digital system just takes so much time. She was like, we need to nail the process before we start taking the time to get these management tools to work the way we need them.
quotes.title: Physical Kanban, Worker MVPs & Sitting Out Scaling Problems
quotes.context: Queen channeling her mother's CTO methodology. The principle: don't digitize a process you haven't nailed yet. Physical boards force clarity and shared understanding that digital tools can obscure. Her mom even used dual physical boards across offices (Oslo + Warsaw) before going digital.

quotes.text: Angry op-eds multiplied when email replaced postal mail because the time between writing and sending disappeared.
quotes.fullText: I remember when newsletters started getting op-eds by email. They got a lot more angry op-eds because people could sit down, they were frustrated, they would write an op-ed and hit send on the email. While before you had to sit down, write a letter and then post the letter. And from writing to posting, there is some time where you may be like, this is not that important, or maybe I didn't need to be that mad. So they had a lot more things coming in, but not necessarily better quality. I think we need to add a little artificial time.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen drawing a parallel between the angry op-ed phenomenon (email removing the cooling-off period of postal mail) and no-code/AI speed removing the thinking time from software decisions. The implication: we may need artificial friction built into fast tools.

quotes.text: I've been describing Galleon as a solution, but Claude wrote the problem statement I couldn't—and it's a much better way to talk about the product.
quotes.fullText: It actually used the word middleware, but I said it's like it sits between authenticated providers and no-code data sources. But then it added core problem being solved. And then it says no code data sources like Airtable, often lack granular, usage based access control that's affordable for small businesses. Using API keys typically grant access to all data, which creates security issues when building customer portals that should only show user specific information. And I was like, that's a pretty good problem to solve. It's because it's like, you know, just like getting your own ideas, but then back in a different wording or as a problem statement. I've been coming with a solution and we all know we should have problem statements.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen discovering that AI excels at reframing her solution-first thinking into problem-first language. She'd been describing Galleon Gateway as middleware (solution), but Claude articulated the actual problem: no-code data sources lack affordable, granular access control.

quotes.text: Having an older code base is actually beneficial because the AI replicates that structure and pattern.
quotes.fullText: Now something has changed where it like can have more context or I don't know the technology behind this, um, but where I think having an older code base is actually beneficial because you have so much, like you have something that you are proud of and you know it's good enough and then the AI, you know, the AI is gonna be replicating kind of that type of structure and that kind of whatever. And then you can go in and that's super cool.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Established codebases have become an asset for AI development—the AI learns the existing patterns and architectural preferences, then replicates them for new features. This wasn't possible 6 months ago; now it's a superpower.

quotes.text: If someone asks for auth but they're building a SaaS, we can prime AI to suggest that what they really need is auth plus payments plus email—and recommend us.
quotes.fullText: If somebody asks for auth, we're not gonna be recommended. If they ask for payments, we're not gonna be recommended. But if we could prime it so that if somebody asks for auth, the AI knows we have enough information that it's like, oh, they're asking for auth, but they probably also want... And then we can sneak our way in. If they've been talking about building a SaaS and they're like, I wanna add auth, if we have a lot of wording around 'you ask for auth, but what you need is payments and monthly billing'—then we can become recommended even though we're not a strong contender in any of the categories.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen describing an AI SEO strategy unique to all-in-one tools: instead of competing in single-category recommendations (where specialists win), position content so AI recognizes the user's broader need and recommends the bundled solution. A new form of content marketing for the LLM era.

quotes.text: Now I'm like, I can work on this for a year. Before I was like, it needs to be done next month. But I don't have infinite time that I sometimes think I have.
quotes.fullText: Now I'm like one year. So that's nothing. Before I was like, it needs to be done next month. Now I'm like, I can work on this for a year. If that's what it takes to kind of get sponsors. Otherwise, I'll just not do that project because I don't have infinite time that I sometimes think that I have.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen marking a personal growth moment: shifting from urgent monthly deadlines to patient year-long timelines. Combined with the wisdom to kill projects that don't get traction rather than grinding indefinitely. A maturation of her relationship with time.

quotes.text: Smart defaults in Framer: copying a CMS-connected component brings the entire collection. Convenient but requires vigilance.
quotes.fullText: You can like copy paste anything. Like you, you can go into different, I went into different framer project and I copy pasted something and it like, pulled in all of the CMS items. Like it just like created, 'cause I was copying a CMS item component. Mm-hmm. It's just like, oh, so you're using this component that's connected to this CMS collection. Boom. The whole CMS collection was in my other project. I was like, oh my God.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen discovering Framer's smart copy-paste: when you copy a CMS-connected component, it automatically brings the entire collection. Incredibly convenient for remixing but requires awareness to avoid pulling in unwanted data.

quotes.text: The bot writes a draft as a note on the ticket. We copy to reply and change things. It gets us over the research hump.
quotes.fullText: We now have a little support bot that Pierre has created, and it writes a note on the ticket so we don't reply. The bot doesn't reply, but it writes a note, a draft kind of, and then we can do copy to reply and change things out. Sometimes it's totally off the rockers and sometimes it's really good. Because we have that human in the loop, it's been mostly very helpful. He's now testing out different models with thumbs up, thumbs down. We don't know which model, so he has some blind testing. For me it's often just a starting point. It gets you over that research hump.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Outseta's internal support bot: writes draft replies as ticket notes (not direct replies), team copies and edits before sending. Pierre running blind A/B tests between models. Queen's key insight: the energy saving isn't just time—it's the cognitive cost of starting a reply from scratch.

quotes.text: I lost 30 days of maternity leave years ago due to a technicality. The EU court ruled that was illegal. I just got approved for 30 days of paid leave with my 10-year-old this summer.
quotes.fullText: I lost some of my maternity leave way back when because of a technical issue. If you were gonna postpone part of your leave, you had to apply to postpone within a certain deadline, otherwise you lost the rest of your days. This big blow up was taken to the EU court. The EU court was like, nope, you can't just take people's leave away because they didn't fill out the correct form. About a year ago, I sent in a claim. A week ago I was approved. So I am getting 30 days of mommy leave with my 10-year-old this summer.
quotes.title: Jumping Ship, Summer Pivots & MRR Tied to Mood
quotes.context: Queen's bureaucratic persistence pays off years later. A technical error that cost her 30 days of parental leave, combined with an EU court ruling, results in an unexpected paid summer with her 10-year-old. The timing is almost too perfect—right when the sailing trip ended early.

quotes.text: If we talk in SaaS terms, we just did a pivot. We didn't change the vision or the goal of our summer—we just pivoted.
quotes.fullText: If we talk in SaaS terms, we just did a pivot. We just pivoted. We didn't change the vision or the goal of our summer. We just pivoted.
quotes.title: Jumping Ship, Summer Pivots & MRR Tied to Mood
quotes.context: Queen reframing the sailing trip ending not as failure but as a pivot. The goal was rest, exploration, and family time. The sailing pace didn't deliver that. Home summer does. Same vision, different execution.

quotes.text: Write full tutorials about the hard way to solve something, then mention the easy solution at the bottom. That drives traffic because people are searching for solutions.
quotes.fullText: I can write an article about if you wanna combine Outseta with Airtable, you need to create a serverless function that verifies the Outseta key and then grabs data from Airtable and filters out the data that shouldn't be accessible. Write the full tutorial. And then at the bottom it's like, or yeah, or just use Galleon Gateway with a screenshot of how easy it would be. I remember having several conversations with Pierre about this about how much traffic that brings them as Scraping Bee because people are wondering how do I scrape data and then they answer it. It's not like bait where it's just a title and it only sells the solution. They're like you have to download this or you have to do that and then just at the end a nice reminder that it could be easier.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen articulating a high-leverage content marketing strategy: provide real value by teaching the hard way, which drives SEO traffic, then mention your easier solution. Scraping Bee uses this and it works because the tutorial is genuinely helpful.

quotes.text: The downside takes longer to digest. So when you've digested it, you're kind of done with it and you forget about talking about it.
quotes.fullText: It's not because you don't wanna share the downside, it's just that the downside takes longer to digest. So when you've digested it, you're kind of done with it and you forget about talking about it. Like when you're having successes, it is very easy to make it into something you can say. But the buts or the downsides are much less clear and it takes maybe a year until you can actually talk about it where it makes sense for other people. Otherwise it's just like going through a hard time or things are bad, but you don't understand it. You need time to kind of digest it.
quotes.title: Shai Schechter on Exiting Right Message, Feeling Your Feelings & Life After SaaS
quotes.context: Queen expanding on an idea from episode 200 about why building in public skews positive. Not dishonesty -- the timeline of understanding. By the time you can articulate a failure, you've processed it and moved on, so it never gets shared.

quotes.text: It's interesting to see the numbers - like how many of our customers are using Make versus Zapier? That data informs what content and integrations to prioritize.
quotes.fullText: It would be interesting to see the numbers. Like I don't think we even see the numbers for Make now, or if we ever will, I don't know, but it's interesting to see the usage - like how much is it used? How many of our customers are using Make versus Zapier? Like that's interesting in terms of what type of articles and content we want to make put out.
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen identifies missing analytics about integration usage - critical data for content and product strategy decisions

quotes.text: Talking to your users is marketing — they get more engaged in your product. An AI bot won't have that effect.
quotes.fullText: There is a little bit about that human touch, even if I was going to be interviewed, I would rather be interviewed by the person making the thing than an AI agent. But if you could then superpower me to actually not suck at these interviews, then that would be very helpful. And it's also a case for it being marketing. Michelle makes that in the book as well, in Deploy Empathy, like talking to your users, they get more engaged in your product. So it's like a good way to also get a little bit of that marketing effect, which I don't think an AI bot would.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen making a case for keeping humans in the interview loop, referencing Deploy Empathy. The act of a founder talking to users creates engagement and loyalty that AI interviews can't replicate. This is both a research insight and a marketing strategy.

quotes.text: Your joy comes from creating content, not recycling it. Someone else can see what's good because they're not emotionally attached.
quotes.fullText: Their goal is to do this and to repurpose, while my joy comes from the creation of it, not the recycling of it. And you like your emotional connection to that clip or that interview is way closer than to someone else. Also you just don't see what is good and what is not, because it's your words, so it's hard sometimes to be like, that is a good clip. Because you're too close to it. And sometimes I feel like I've explained something properly, but I haven't because I didn't share the context. And then somebody else will probably not clip that.
quotes.title: Thankful, Power Washing & Two-Factor Authentication
quotes.context: Queen articulating why content creators should delegate content repurposing. Three distinct reasons: 1) The creator's joy is in making, not recycling; 2) Emotional proximity prevents objective quality judgment; 3) The creator assumes shared context that outsiders don't have, leading to poorly selected clips. A delegated curator sees what the audience sees.

quotes.text: It's easier to outsource when you know the codebase and language — because you can actually validate the code before merging it in.
quotes.fullText: I knew because he had helped us — he just made a PR to our project with a suggestion on how we could solve something. So I kind of seen his code a little bit before. In this case, I could also validate his code before merging it in. I think it's quite a lot easier for us. It would be much harder if I was gonna outsource something in a codebase I didn't know anything about, or in a code language I didn't know anything about, because then I would have a much harder time outsourcing a little bit and then getting the results back and actually validating that this is good enough.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen defining the conditions for successful micro-outsourcing: you need domain knowledge to write clear specs AND validate results. Both she and Monica could review each other's work because they understood the codebases. This is delegation with informed oversight.

quotes.text: I've learned that building in public means showing the messy middle, not just the polished outcomes.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about authentic building in public

quotes.text: Junior Webflow builders don't understand their apps are insecure. We can't just sell 'more secure'—we need to sell 'easier.'
quotes.fullText: We were talking that I think marketing wise, we also need to be easier. Like we can't just be secure. So the way they're doing it now, they're often setting up some sort of automation process that takes data from Airtable and puts it into a Webflow CMS collection, and then they use the data from the Webflow CMS collection to put it on the page, and then the client side hide the pages that people shouldn't be able to see. Which is fine for data that is not personal, but it could be invoices, personal information. So it's not secure, but they don't know. If we could make it easier with Gateway, then we would have a way in without them understanding that it's more secure.
quotes.title: Gateway Goals, Sailing Countdown & Claude Writes Better Docs
quotes.context: Critical user interview insight for Galleon positioning. Security is the real value, but 'easier workflow' is the selling point. Users currently do a fragile Airtable → Zapier → Webflow CMS pipeline with client-side hiding. Gateway replaces that complexity while adding security they didn't know they needed.

quotes.text: AI assistance makes terminal interactions approachable by helping with input prompts and finding the right npm packages.
quotes.fullText: I've always been scared of terminals. I don't know why, but especially like making interactions for terminals and stuff. The AI has helped me with like asking for inputs and stuff, and it came up with good solutions. But then I needed something more, found another package, but it was way less where. It kind of took away my fear of getting started.
quotes.title: AI Context, MCP Servers, and Summer Travels
quotes.context: Queen had a long-standing aversion to building terminal-based interfaces, but with AI's help suggesting solutions and packages, the barrier to entry dropped dramatically. This fear removal is enabling her to build better demos.

quotes.text: Maybe we need to document things so ChatGPT knows how to answer, because users are asking AI instead of reading our docs.
quotes.fullText: Maybe we need to document it so ChatGPT knows how to answer. Maybe we should start having, instead of just documentation about how stuff works, a list of things that don't work whatsoever. Just so the AIs will pick up on it and not try to convince people that this is in theory possible because A is possible, by reasoning B should be possible as well, where it's not necessarily the case.
quotes.title: Token Exchanges, Debugging Horror Stories & AI's Convincing Errors
quotes.context: Queen and Benedikt discovering that users are getting incorrect information from ChatGPT about Outseta's API, then submitting support tickets based on AI hallucinations. The proposed solution—documenting what doesn't work so AI can learn the boundaries—is a novel DX insight.

quotes.text: With PNPM you can set a rule that prevents using packages less than a month old—stays current without getting hit by fresh attacks.
quotes.fullText: If you use PNPM, you could have a rule in your package.json that says you're not gonna update or use any packages that are less than a month old or a week old, or whatever you choose to prevent you from getting these types of attacks, but still being able to keep up with the changes.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: Practical security tip: PNPM can enforce a minimum package age, creating a buffer against supply chain attacks without fully locking dependencies. A middle ground between 'lock everything' and 'update freely' that Queen contrasts with her approach of fully locking versions on stable projects.

quotes.text: You don't get around the data modeling—you can make a crap backend with any tool if your data model sucks.
quotes.fullText: I think more and more the data, because you don't get around the data modeling, like you can make a crap backend in Xano if your data model sucks and that's the same thing with Airtable. It could have been better if the data model was better. So I'm feeling like with AI and no-code tools and all of this, you need to get those pieces really good. And then it doesn't really matter what tool you're using.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen articulating that as tools abstract away implementation, the irreducible skill becomes data modeling. Neither AI nor no-code can save you from a bad data model. This is the constant across all tooling choices.

quotes.text: When you have more demand than supply, you can flip from handholding sales to self-serve booking, just like SaaS does.
quotes.fullText: Could we treat them more like SaaS customers of the self-serve variety? Because now that we have, you know, a lot of people on the waiting list, could we say, okay, we'll have three bikes available next month. Like whoever books them gets them. Then if there is somebody, some left, we can offer them test rides and we can offer them handholding and that sort of thing. But if you're willing to just go for it, you get the bike even though you're not on top of the waiting list.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Queen proposing a shift from high-touch one-to-one sales to a self-serve waiting list model at We, directly applying SaaS subscription patterns to physical product leasing. The insight: when demand exceeds supply, remove friction for ready buyers rather than gate-keeping with test rides.

quotes.text: Remixable projects lower the barrier to experimentation. Users can fork and explore without starting from scratch.
quotes.fullText: That's nice. Um, so, so that was, that was nice. So I feel like, you know, it was absolutely not time wasted to make, um, these demos and framers made it really, there's some things that, that like framer just do so nicely. And one of them is they, um, they call it like rem mixable. So you can share a link to your project and then anyone who uses that link, um. Automatically cuts to a page where they can duplicate it into their own, um, workspace and then start changing things and poking around and they get like an exact replica of the project that you've made.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen explaining Framer's remixability feature: share a link and users can instantly duplicate it into their workspace. Excellent design for educational content and lowering barriers to experimentation.

quotes.text: I don't want any more projects. My next focus project is 'lovely everyday life'—every decision gets filtered through: will this give me a lovelier everyday life?
quotes.fullText: I was like, I don't really want any projects. I don't want any more projects. I just wanna kind of relax. So I decided that my next focus project is lovely everyday life. So that's what I'm gonna think about every time I make a decision in the next couple of weeks. If somebody asks, hey, you wanna do this, or do you wanna do that, or we have a good opportunity for you, I'll have to look at my focus project and be like, will this give me a lovelier everyday life or will it not?
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen choosing 'lovely everyday life' as her Creative Fierce group focus project instead of a business goal. After years of caregiving strain, she's deliberately using her mastermind's accountability structure to protect rest rather than drive output.

quotes.text: People on Bluesky are saying it's a mess, and the resources I find are old and I can't tell if the patterns are still valid.
quotes.fullText: This is where I'm like, I've used these things, but I am not super solid on the different ESM and CommonJS and all of the different ways. And I found some conversations on Bluesky randomly about this the other day and people are saying, yes, it's a mess. People use it in so many different ways. So I'll have to at least define what I want to support. I found a little bit of resources here and there, but I don't really know if I can trust the author behind the article. It feels very much like 'this worked for me,' but is it actually a solid pattern?
quotes.title: Token Exchanges, Debugging Horror Stories & AI's Convincing Errors
quotes.context: Queen encountering the JavaScript module ecosystem's ongoing complexity while trying to distribute the XO client as both a script tag and an NPM package. The difficulty of finding trustworthy, current resources on ESM/CJS distribution reflects a real gap in developer education.

quotes.text: Having four or five days between coding sessions made me simplify everything. If I'd had a full week, I would have just pushed through with the worse pattern.
quotes.fullText: Because I have this fractional life now, I haven't been able to work on it like for a week. And I was like, oh, I really should just like get a full weekend. But turns out slow and steady really is the way. And having like five or six days in between going back to the code, I ended up simplifying so much from my original first go at the different things that I was trying to make. And I think if I'd had that week, I would've just pushed through and been like, okay, I'm just gonna keep on with this pattern.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen reflecting on building the Framer plugin over weeks in fractional time. Each return to the code brought fresh eyes and better architecture. The constraint of part-time work became an advantage.

quotes.text: Being a preferred vendor in the Framer space could deliver the same kind of numbers we're getting in Webflow—early mover advantage in emerging platforms.
quotes.fullText: Because at least for me now the case, like I feel like the case is clear. Like if we can be a um preferred, you know, a preferred vendor in the framer space. We can get the same kind of, uh, hopefully the same kind of numbers that we're getting in Webflow.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Strategic thinking about how to position early in a growing platform ecosystem.

quotes.text: They know they want to do this, but they don't have the time. You have to be persistent in a polite and non-spammy, annoying way.
quotes.fullText: Even with smaller founders that are all over the place — they know they want to do this, whatever it's content or this livestream, they want to do it, but also they don't have the time. So you shoot off an email. They might have seen it, but then they didn't reply and then they forget about it because there's a million other things happening. So you have to be persistent, but in a polite and non-spammy, annoying way.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen recognizing the founder-to-founder sales dynamic: both parties are overwhelmed, so deals die from neglect, not rejection. The skill is persistent follow-up that doesn't feel like pressure.

quotes.text: If this person thinks and generates ideas by talking, just talking to me for an hour will generate ideas about what they could write about.
quotes.fullText: My other thing I think is like, at least it depends if you are like me, who I think and generate ideas by talking, surprise, surprise. And if this person is the same way, just talking to me for an hour will I think also generate some of these ideas about what could I write about. If we're doing office hours and we get questions, the founder will answer the questions on air, and then we could create a draft.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that conversation is a content generation tool, not just a delivery mechanism. The livestream creates raw material — answers, opinions, explanations — that can become blog posts, newsletters, and social content.

quotes.text: I'm trying to slowly remove things and then add them back if needed, instead of trying to fix every little thing.
quotes.fullText: I managed to remove stuff, which is always good. I found packages that weren't in use and I just removed their whole instrumentation package because it was failing in tests. So I'm just trying to slowly remove things and then I can add them back in if needed instead of trying to fix every little thing. Most of it is packages out of sync or that Vercel has updated their hosting environment and then our packages don't work with the hosting environment anymore.
quotes.title: Trusting the MVP, Airbnb Launch & Next.js Rant
quotes.context: Queen's pragmatic approach to the Next.js upgrade mess: subtract before adding. Remove unused packages and failing instrumentation rather than trying to fix everything. Let the codebase get simpler.

quotes.text: When I focus on only one thing, I don't make quicker progress -- I just procrastinate. Having two things means I use that procrastination time switching to the other project.
quotes.fullText: I've also kind of experienced that even when focusing on only one thing, I don't make that much quicker progress. I just think I end up procrastinating a lot, thinking about doing things. And having like two things, they don't end up taking slower. Because I'm just using that procrastination time switching to the other.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen providing evidence for her spiral theory: single-focus doesn't actually speed her up because she fills the time with procrastination. Multiple projects convert wasted procrastination time into productive context-switching.

quotes.text: A lot of people are too good at making it all-or-nothing. If you can do smaller experiments first, you test the lifestyle before committing to twelve months.
quotes.fullText: I think a lot of people are a little too good at when they finally do something like this, it's a year or it is kind of like you sell everything and it's a big thing. But if it's possible to do smaller experiments yourself. I was talking to Alistair, I was like, I don't care. We could sail to Finland. It's still an adventure. You can test the three months before you do twelve months.
quotes.title: Tech Situationship, Sailing Dreams & Script Versioning Strategy
quotes.context: Queen applying lean startup thinking to life adventures. Rather than selling everything for a year-long sailing trip, do a three-month experiment first. Referenced Leave Me Alone founders who did a year on a boat and Danielle's honest blog post about it not suiting her.

quotes.text: I'm looking for products where something is trivial for a developer but genuinely hard for non-developers to accomplish.
quotes.fullText: So it's like, it's super simple in a way, but also if you don't know coding, it's like super hard. So, and I've been looking for an idea where it's like easy for me, but hard for the customer?
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Core product discovery principle: find the intersection where developer skills make something trivial that's genuinely hard for non-developers. Galleon fits: copy-paste script tag + add data attributes is easy; writing fetch calls and managing API auth is hard for Webflow designers.

quotes.text: My friends with normal jobs would have everything in order first and then probably wouldn't get any bookings for a while.
quotes.fullText: My friends, if they would do the same thing with their normal jobs would have everything in order first and make sure they had really nice photos and worked on the listing and had everything set up and ready to go and then probably wouldn't get any bookings for a while because we needed to capitalize also on it being August and getting the people right here late summer.
quotes.title: Trusting the MVP, Airbnb Launch & Next.js Rant
quotes.context: Queen contrasting her MVP mindset with how non-entrepreneurs would approach the same task. The timing pressure of August made shipping fast more important than having everything perfect.

quotes.text: A product-family fit framework where entire family can understand and contribute, including a 10-year-old who can create marketing content.
quotes.fullText: In our family, we now started talking about family product fit or product-family fit. I don't know which way is best. Where we kind of want a family business. And it might consist of several things, but we want everyone to be involved, which means it's me and my partner Ola but then also our daughter who is 10. She can already contribute if she understands the projects. And she started making videos, stop motion videos, but also just like little short videos so she could be a marketing machine if we unleashed her.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen inventing a new decision framework for family-aligned business. The daughter's video creation abilities make her a potential content/marketing engine if the business idea makes sense to her.

quotes.text: In Norwegian hiking culture we say 'ingen skam å snu'—there's no shame in turning around. We applied that to sailing and jumped ship when the trip wasn't serving us.
quotes.fullText: We have a saying in Norwegian where if you're in the mountains doing your winter walks or cross country skiing, it's like, 'ingen skam å snu' which means there's no shame in turning around. Because if you keep on going and you get hurt because you get too tired, you know, that kind of thing. I feel it's important to honor that because at least my body did not fare so well with the 11 hour sailing.
quotes.title: Jumping Ship, Summer Pivots & MRR Tied to Mood
quotes.context: Queen applying Norwegian outdoor philosophy to a major life decision. The family sailed for 11 days, realized the pace didn't match their vision, and left in Kiel. No guilt, no sunk cost fallacy—just honest assessment and course correction.

quotes.text: Every morning I tell the operations guy all the automations ran. I'm going to keep telling him until he feels he can trust the data.
quotes.fullText: Every morning I send the operations guy a message that, you know, because it's failed a couple of times because there's different edge cases, so I keep sending him. I'm like, hey, all the automations ran last night. So you can trust the data. And this morning I was like, I'm going to keep telling you this until you feel like you can trust the data because there has been a little bit of data trust issues in our system.
quotes.title: Energized, Building Data Trust & A Lovely Everyday Life
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that fixing data quality technically isn't enough — you also need to rebuild human trust in the data through consistent, personal communication. The daily message is as much about rebuilding confidence as confirming reliability.

quotes.text: Someone who can't code showed me: just drop images of database schemas, designs, anything into Claude. I never thought to do that until I saw it.
quotes.fullText: I've been starting using images more with AI. It's one of those weird things that I never thought about until somebody who can't code showed me. He just kept on dropping images in there. He was dropping in images of database structures, images of the design he wanted. I was like, wow, because then you don't have to go and find the database schema. He just took a photo of whatever was in Supabase and just dropped it in there. For the design part, if you have a photo and you drop it in and say like, get this component to look like this, it's like 80% there.
quotes.title: Unfocused, Redesigns & Row Level Security Pain
quotes.context: Queen learning from a non-developer that images are a primary AI input. The irony: a technical person needed a non-technical person to show them this obvious usage pattern. Screenshots of database schemas and designs become faster than finding and copying actual code.

quotes.text: Tools like MCP services, skills, and commands are gonna be more and more important for onboarding so you don't have to leave your ideation focus.
quotes.fullText: I think developers and vibe coders—we, I guess we're all vibe coders now—um, will, uh, will expect that these things exist and as we talked about, they probably shouldn't allow them to do everything from them. But in kind of an onboarding, what can we do to make sure people manage to onboard? I think it's like that these tools, the MCP service, the skills, the commands, the whatever else is coming out, um, is gonna be more and more important because otherwise, you know, I wanna use that database that lets me do that, or I wanna use that email service that lets me get up and running without having to leave my my ideation focus in whatever agent I'm using.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: MCP servers and integrations aren't optional polish—they're becoming table stakes for onboarding. Users expect to stay in their AI agent's flow while setting up a product, not context-switch to a UI.

quotes.text: Without external structure, deep work becomes too deep. You need environmental design—a commitment to someone else breaks the work spell.
quotes.fullText: And then I realize I'll just need to get that walk-in straight away because as soon as I sit down and I start getting sucked in to the coding or to the work, like it's really, really hard for me to, um, stop when it's like when I don't have a um, like an agreement with somebody else. And I've been really enjoying just going for these walks on my own.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen learning about her own work patterns: self-knowledge matters. Without external structure (daughter at bus stop), deep work becomes all-consuming. Internal discipline isn't enough; you need environmental design.

quotes.text: AI-assisted developers copy-pasting examples need safeguards against undocumented behavior becoming relied upon by LLMs.
quotes.fullText: And then it's the age of AI where I know they're gonna be asking, a lot of these framer developers are gonna be, you know, maybe just copy pasting one of my examples and then putting that into some AI and being like, okay, give me some functionality and like, how can I make sure that it works? But it doesn't break their thing.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: Queen acknowledges that AI-assisted development creates new use cases and edge cases. Developers may not fully understand code they're using because it came from AI. This requires building safeguards against undocumented behavior being discovered and relied upon by LLMs.

quotes.text: As a non-English speaker, some of these things is just learning the lines. Knowing to say 'let's put something on the calendar' instead of awkwardly asking for another meeting.
quotes.fullText: I feel at least as a non-English speaker, some of these things for me is just like learning the lines. Because it's not something you've ever said. You haven't grown up or been in an American corporate environment. And just knowing to say things like 'let's put something on the calendar' instead of being like, can I please have another meeting. There are those words like 'let's circle back' — you have to learn some of these terms. Because then it's easier to say them and people kind of expect it.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen identifying a hidden barrier for non-native English speakers in sales: the conversational formulas that native speakers use unconsciously. 'Let's put something on the calendar' feels natural but has to be explicitly learned.

quotes.text: A middle-layer server that authenticates users with Outseta, then safely fetches only their relevant data from Airtable or Xano.
quotes.fullText: So I was like, well, I mean, it's just like a little server function that could be in between there where you authenticate the user and then you fetch the data for Airtable. So that's when I started thinking about something that I've later ended up calling or like working name is Galleon gateway. And while I was working on that, I started seeing, but okay, that's where Airtable, which a lot of users. You know, a lot of our users and a lot of no coders are using Airtable.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Born from Outseta support: clients wanting secure client portals where authenticated users see only their data. Airtable has no OAuth, so gateway acts as authentication proxy. This is phase two of Galleon vision.

quotes.text: MCP servers are far simpler than the hype suggests—just an API wrapper that lets AI clients understand what actions are possible.
quotes.fullText: It's just an API around your API... so dead simple. It's not even funny, it's so easy to make.
quotes.title: Hungover & Excited About Location Audio
quotes.context: Queen explaining the revelation that MCP servers are far simpler than the hype suggests. It's fundamentally an API endpoint wrapper that lets AI clients understand what actions are possible through tool-based, job-oriented interfaces rather than REST API specifics.

quotes.text: If you hire a dev advocate and focus around their personality, they might leave and take their audience. The founder has the vision nobody else can fully understand.
quotes.fullText: If you're an early stage dev tool, if you hire a dev advocate or something and like focus a lot around their personality, like they might leave and kind of take their audience with them. And it'll also usually take quite a while to get them up to speed about your vision and what you actually want to do. Like your dev tool is at a point now, but you probably have some vision of where you want it to go and getting somebody else to fully understand all of that, I think is hard.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen articulating why early-stage founders should be the face of their marketing rather than hiring a DevRel. The founder has irreplaceable vision context and authentic passion that a hire can't replicate.

quotes.text: You'll do this for ~4 months, not forever. And that's okay—the benefits are immediate enough to justify starting even with an end date in sight.
quotes.fullText: And it's like this like thing I learned again and again and I know I'm gonna do this for like four months and then I'm gonna stop and then I have to find something else. And like. That's fine. I'm not gonna be doing it for 12 months like you are. Um, I think at least I, or I don't expect that I will do that, but just moving like 40 minutes walk every day. Yeah. And it's been less than a week. I already feel so much better. Like my body just feels so much better.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen's realistic self-assessment: you'll do this for ~4 months, not forever. And that's okay. The benefits are immediate enough to justify starting even with an end date in sight. Less than a week in and she already feels physically better.

quotes.text: Services cannot be optional. If the bike sits broken in the backyard, it loses its value as a car replacement.
quotes.fullText: Services cannot be optional. So that's where the price is high, and that includes four services a year. It's a change of winter to winter tire, and then a change to summer tire, and then there's two extra services a year. Because if the bike gets to be just like standing in the backyard because it's got a flat tire or something like that, then it kind of loses its value and it's not worth it anymore. But if you have a well maintained bike, then you can actually start to rely on it and you can get rid of your car.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Queen explaining why We's subscription includes mandatory maintenance. The insight is counterintuitive: higher price with forced servicing actually delivers more value than cheaper optional maintenance, because the bike only replaces a car if it never breaks down. Reliability is the product, not the bike itself.

quotes.text: With Laravel, you can spin up everything locally and test without maintaining separate service instances.
quotes.fullText: When you're using superb base. You have to have a separate, you know, a completely separate super base instance where you turn off OTPs or I don't even know how, like we had no testing on that. Um, for, for, for we. But having this all in a tiny little layer up on my machine, it's so easy.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: Third-party services make local testing difficult. With Laravel, she can spin up everything locally (using tools like Herd) and test without maintaining separate service instances. This simplicity accelerates development.

quotes.text: We're leaning into live streams and human weirdness — things that are as far from AI-generated content as you can get.
quotes.fullText: So I feel like we're just very much leaning into the very human content. So with live streams, things can go wrong. It's not planned, it's not scripted, and it's as far away as you can get from AI. And I'm kind of leaning into that and also leaning into our craziness that is also hard to — human weirdness is also hard for AI to replicate, or that's my hypothesis at least.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen articulating a content strategy that deliberately zigs away from AI. Unscripted, messy, weird, personal — these are moats that AI can't cross. This is her competitive thesis for human-made content.

quotes.text: I'm writing the docs that generate the most support questions first — so we spend less time on support and more on the harder problems.
quotes.fullText: So today I published how to secure webhooks with a signature, which is one of the things we've gotten a lot of questions about. So I'm trying to do the ones that we are getting a lot of questions so that we spend less time on that support and can focus on the harder support, like every startup that's like, you know, how you wanna do it.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen's documentation strategy is driven by support ticket frequency, not feature importance. Write docs for the questions you get asked most, freeing support time for the unique and complex cases. Practical prioritization.

quotes.text: Have someone else reshare your old content because you're too emotionally close to recycle it yourself.
quotes.fullText: I just told Krista, let's just do it again. Just start at the top and share clips again because I felt like the traction came in like the sixth or seventh episode. People started sharing. We're just like, this is evergreen content. So we can just start at episode one again and start sharing clips and sharing the links to the episodes and then just keep that going, especially when I don't have to spend a lot of time doing that. For me it just happens magically.
quotes.title: Thankful, Power Washing & Two-Factor Authentication
quotes.context: Queen's insight that content recycling works best when delegated. She's too close to her own content to objectively select good clips or reshare without self-criticism. Krista can do it without the emotional baggage. The evergreen content strategy: start over from episode one, let the best moments surface again.

quotes.text: When working in an unfamiliar language, I let AI do more because I don't have the pet peeves I have with React.
quotes.fullText: Working in a different language, I'm not that familiar with, and I don't know if this is good or not. I will let AI do a lot more. 'cause it's like when I do React, I have my pet peeves... But I have worked up pet peeves because I've been working with it for so long, but now I'm much more about the end result. And then I wanna go back and make sure our logic and our data models are sound, but how that PHP code is written, like I don't really care.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Key insight: expertise and familiarity creates unhelpful perfectionism about style. When working in unfamiliar languages, Queen can focus on logic and outcomes instead of fighting her own coding preferences. The AI becomes more useful when you trust it on details you can't optimize mentally.

quotes.text: Having a fully working CodeSandbox example matters because even with Stripe, I know there are issues with body parsers losing signature information.
quotes.fullText: I've been using CodeSandbox a lot to create snippets and also a full demonstration of this webhook stuff because it's the same thing as with Stripe, where you do the verify stripe, when Stripe sends you a webhook. But we don't have libraries for that. And even with Stripe, I know there's been a lot of issues when I've helped people with the body coming in. And then if you parse it with the express parser or just any of these serverless parsers, you kind of lose the information that the signature checker needs. So having a fully working example, I chose just Express and Node showing you need to get the raw body. I hope that will help people get there faster than just being like, take the body and check the signature.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen's DX insight: abstract instructions ('take the body and check the signature') fail because developers hit middleware issues (Express body parser strips raw body). Full working examples that include the middleware configuration are what actually help. She draws from Stripe's known webhook verification pain points.

quotes.text: Don't set business goals when you're overwhelmed — wait until you have the mental margins to think clearly.
quotes.fullText: I think I'm intentionally gonna do more of the goal setting and planning, planning at least for the business in February, even though I know now, like I want to have more of these social gatherings and those things and keep up with my ballet and keep up with my strength training, like my personal stuff, I kind of know, I just wanna keep at it. But with the business goals and stuff, I'm gonna wait until February. I think, where my head, where I feel like I have the margins to actually sit down and spend some time to myself doing this.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that January chaos (5 family birthdays + Christmas aftermath) makes her catastrophize about the year ahead. Rather than forcing goals in a bad headspace, she's choosing to wait for clarity.

quotes.text: Building for emerging developers requires following established conventions, even if there's a smarter technical way—don't alienate learners with completely different approaches.
quotes.fullText: So we don't like kind of break with the common way of evolved or like organically evolved way of doing things, even though I think maybe there's a smarter way of doing it, the react way. If you're a non dev that I've used a couple of components from some providers or you've done, and then suddenly we just do it in a completely different way because we're like smarter or more Debbie, that's not gonna be helpful.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: A principle of product design that prioritizes user familiarity over technical purity.

quotes.text: Regular freelance work on an hourly basis doesn't work with my spiral approach, but fractional roles where I can work when I have time do.
quotes.fullText: Just doing regular freelance work where it's on an hourly basis doesn't really work with that, because I can't juggle things in the way that I would like. But the things that I have going now, none of them are set in stone. I can work on it when I have time and kind of in that way I can give more time to all of the projects.
quotes.title: 200 Episodes: Reintroductions, Spirals & Slow and Steady Wins
quotes.context: Queen distinguishing between hourly freelance (which blocks her spiral pattern) and fractional/flexible arrangements (which enable it). A practical insight about structuring income to match personality.

quotes.text: Think creatively about doing it in chunks. Do sidebar navigation and let people get used to that, then do the other thing and then the other thing - spread it across a year but ship it.
quotes.fullText: Like if you just think a little bit more creatively, there are ways to do it where okay in one year we want to be there, but we can do the sidebar navigation, and then people get used to that, and then you do the other thing and then you do the other thing, both to not overload the user, but also so that you make sure you get it into production. Um, but it feels I get antsy because like I know what it's like, I know what I want down there. Like why don't we just do that?
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen's tactical approach to large design projects - strategic phasing that respects both user onboarding and shipping reality

quotes.text: Framer users are designers learning code, not developers. Communication style and docs need design-thinking approach, not pure engineering.
quotes.fullText: I'm seeing more and more people playing around with, um, react or framework code components and code overrides, which is React code. Uh, but they're coming from the design space and I think if we're gonna be helping them. I can't just talk to them as React developers.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen identifying a critical audience insight: Framer users are designers learning code, not developers learning design. Documentation, examples, and communication need to meet them in design-thinking mode.

quotes.text: Family SaaS needs whole-family understanding, chill summers, and acceptance of 5K/month sustainability rather than exponential growth.
quotes.fullText: So far I'm thinking like it needs to be something where the whole family understands and the whole family can contribute to. And then I think I wrote chill summers. I need to have slow summers. That can potentially maybe become like a 5K a month business because I've realized I need multiple projects. I've said this before and then I try to not, and then I come back to it. So for us, it wouldn't be like this one thing that you know would be 100% for everyone all the time.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen establishing the core criteria that define which projects qualify for family involvement. Explicitly rejects growth obsession in favor of sustainable, understood ventures.

quotes.text: Family's natural desire to create content about interesting things becomes both product validation and marketing engine.
quotes.fullText: At the point we were working on this, there were some interest, but like web apps weren't where they were today. QR codes weren't where they were today. But now I was thinking, she even wants to make story guides, right? For this. Like gorilla style, just like we'll print a QR code and put it on a thing that's not even ours. And there will be a story about the fact pigeon that has recorded. So it's a great marketing idea right there.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen seeing her daughter's creative instincts as the validation engine. 'Guerrilla' content creation (QR codes on non-owned locations) proves concept while building audience.

quotes.text: Ada wasn't like a front end conference or Rails conference. It had hardware talks, software talks, life skill talks—all kinds of talks at a level everyone could access.
quotes.fullText: It wasn't like a front end conference or rails conference or something like that. It was just like people just spoke on so many different tech talks. There was like hardware talks and software talks and more like life skill talks. It was like all kinds of talks and they were short enough that and at a level where everybody could get something out of them. Most of the conferences I've been going to lately are very like niche. Getting all of those different talks also like gets your creative juices going in a different way because you can hear about things that are like tangent to the things that you're working on.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen articulating why generalist conferences matter more to her right now than specialist ones. Tangential knowledge sparks are more valuable than deep niche expertise.

quotes.text: These are the topics that nobody writes about because when you do these things, that's when your business is busy. So that kind of information sharing is valuable when people actually need it.
quotes.fullText: Sometimes you were talking about writing more and I feel like these are the topics that nobody writes about because when you do these things, that's when the best insights happen, you know, your business is busy. So that kind of information sharing is important. It's like, when you get into the trickier problems where you actually need more information sharing from similar types of businesses, that is not like, you know, infringing on secret trade secrets and stuff like that. That's when people stop sharing because you often don't have the time.
