quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen identifies the paradox of technical content - most valuable when businesses are executing (but have least time to write), leading to knowledge gaps

quotes.text: When all API keys must be personal, removing a departed employee's account takes down every integration they set up.
quotes.fullText: All across the board you need to have a personal account. And then most of these systems now don't have kind of system API keys, all API keys have to be personal. So the last dev guy, he'd created API keys. So if we remove his user, all systems go down because none of the API keys are then valid anymore because they have to be created for me or for somebody else and then added back in. Because they're all personal API keys instead of kind of system wide API keys.
quotes.title: Thankful, Power Washing & Two-Factor Authentication
quotes.context: Queen identifying a systemic problem in the no-code and SaaS world: the push toward personal API keys (for security) creates fragile systems where a single person's departure can break every integration. In small teams, 'more secure' personal credentials actually create worse outcomes because they become unmanageable single points of failure.

quotes.text: I chatted with Claude on a train and it produced a full project overview, implementation plan, and context document in under an hour—better than I could formulate it.
quotes.fullText: I kind of asked it to export a kind of high level overview, and I put that into Claude and then kept chatting with Claude, and then saying what I needed, it came up with some like implementation examples and then I was like, but how do I get this into Cursor? I asked Claude to give me context document that I could feed into Cursor and blew my mind. It was so good 'cause it kind of like outlined everything that's needed. The controllers, the first, it gave me a project overview about like, what is the goal of this project and it's so much better at formulating it than me.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen describing her new AI workflow: brainstorm in ChatGPT, export to Claude, get structured planning documents to feed into Cursor. The key insight is that AI formulates project goals and architecture better than she can—not because it knows more, but because it structures thinking clearly.

quotes.text: Higher-price enterprise customers aren't spending their Christmas holiday fiddling with tools — they need a sales process and human guidance.
quotes.fullText: Those kinds of people often need a lot of handholding and special sales or outreach and they're not spending their Christmas holiday just fiddling with tools. While for Outseta, with our price point, that is exactly the type of customer that we are geared towards — somebody who wants kind of everything in one place for a lower price point.
quotes.title: Confused, Energized & Year Compass Reflections
quotes.context: Queen articulating how price point determines customer behavior and sales motion. Lower price = self-serve Christmas fiddlers. Higher price = need demos and hand-holding.

quotes.text: Working with the data like this gives me better gut feeling knowledge that will be helpful when we have the time and money to do larger changes.
quotes.fullText: I feel like just working with the data like that, it's giving me better, some kind of more gut feeling knowledge around the data that will be helpful when we have the time and money to do some larger changes.
quotes.title: Energized, Building Data Trust & A Lovely Everyday Life
quotes.context: Queen articulating the hidden benefit of doing manual data reconciliation work: you develop intuition about the business's data patterns that no dashboard can give you. This gut knowledge will inform better architectural decisions later.

quotes.text: We can position against AI: our generated worker is deterministic. Same options, same code, every time. AI gives you something 80% right if you're specific—and much worse if you're not.
quotes.fullText: We can also position it a little bit as, we can actually kind of position ourselves against AI, like we're deterministic. Like you will get the same worker if you do the same options every time. And you can come back and do it again. I've asked AI to do similar things again and again. I have a feeling around 80-90% if I'm very specific. But the people needing this, they don't know what to ask for. And when I ask it more in a general fashion, is it secure? No. Very often it's not.
quotes.title: Physical Kanban, Worker MVPs & Sitting Out Scaling Problems
quotes.context: Queen finding Galleon's competitive angle against AI code generation: deterministic, correct output every time. AI is probabilistic and often insecure. For security-critical code like auth workers, 80% correct isn't good enough.

quotes.text: Even though webhooks are reliable, I run nightly automations that fetch current status in case one or two webhooks go missing.
quotes.fullText: Even though Stripe is super reliable and Make seems to be super reliable, I also wanted to have nightly automations that also just fetched current status in case one or two webhooks go missing. I want to make sure that we are up to date. A little bit of overkill, but I just wanted to do a little bit of over-engineering now to make sure that we are capturing everything.
quotes.title: Energized, Building Data Trust & A Lovely Everyday Life
quotes.context: Queen implementing a belt-and-suspenders approach to data reliability: real-time webhooks plus nightly reconciliation. For a physical product business where missing a failed payment means bikes in the wild, the over-engineering is justified.

quotes.text: I took some hours off where I just laid on the couch and watched television and didn't feel bad about it—that's the perk of this life, the flexibility.
quotes.fullText: I felt like I was trying to code, it just didn't work, like the brain wasn't working, I wasn't feeling it. And I was like, okay, I'm actually tired. And I took some hours off before this podcast where I just laid on the couch and watched some television and didn't feel bad about it. Because that's the perks of this life, right? We need to enjoy or, you know, take the perks. Flexibility. I guess it's the only major perk and it's a huge one.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: This is foundational to sustainable product building—recognizing tiredness, honoring it, and using entrepreneurial flexibility to rest without guilt.

quotes.text: Tiny, remixable SaaS projects that showcase authentication, backend integration, and React patterns—bridging the gap between design and code for developers learning.
quotes.fullText: I suddenly I think I had a really great idea for marketing, um, of the framer, like framer outside of combo. And that is making tiny, tiny little SaaS in framer. Um. So like showcasing, because there's a lot of people doing, um, educational content around the design and kind of basic setting up of the sites. But if we could do some, uh, rem mixable projects that have a backend and some proper react code and outside as the authentication.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: A breakthrough idea that serves dual purposes—demonstrating capabilities while being educational and remixable for the audience.

quotes.text: Launches bundle things into a week that you can tie to something—a point in time that creates momentum.
quotes.fullText: It's a point in time, place... you can bundle it up where it's like, this is our week... you can like tie it to something.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen articulating how 'launch weeks' for features that have been live for months still create value by creating a marker in time. It's a PR/communication tool, not a product release tool.

quotes.text: I might chip away until there's only a React app left and then I can move it out of Next.
quotes.fullText: I might chip away until there's only a React app left and then I can move it out of Next.
quotes.title: Trusting the MVP, Airbnb Launch & Next.js Rant
quotes.context: Queen's pragmatic migration strategy for the Whee codebase: instead of rewriting from scratch, gradually remove Next.js-specific code until the logged-in pages are a pure React SPA that can be extracted. Resisting the temptation to rewrite entirely.

quotes.text: Make a clickbait title without it being clickbait because it's actually what happened. Like 'I spent a Saturday with this tool, our cloud bills are down 50%' - it wouldn't be a lie.
quotes.fullText: It's a tip of, you know, like we use this tool and it could make a clickbait title without it being clickbait because it's actually what happened. Like I spent a Saturday with this tool, our cloud bills are down 50%, you know, and it wouldn't be, and it wouldn't be a lie. It would just be a true clickbaity article or whatever.
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen's framework for writing compelling technical content that honestly conveys business impact

quotes.text: I saw the tweet 'The Code is Your Enemy' and was like, yes, yes, I know. But I've been coding anyway. So now Ola is doing the user interviews.
quotes.fullText: I came on this little tweet from Jason asmartbear, founder of WPEngine, where he was saying, don't code the thing, talk to people first. And I was like, oh, yeah, yeah. I've heard that before. The blog post is called The Code is Your Enemy. I've done this for products before, talked to people. But this time I just wanted to code because I'm so certain I can build this. But that's not the hard part with this project. So Ola and I had a walk and talk today where we came up with a plan where he's gonna recruit people from the Webflow Forum and Reddit.
quotes.title: Unfocused, Redesigns & Row Level Security Pain
quotes.context: Queen catching herself in the classic founder trap: coding before validating. The self-awareness is there ('I know, I know') but the pull to build is strong. Solution: delegate the customer interviews to Ola so she doesn't skip them.

quotes.text: ChatGPT is surprisingly good at the boilerplate JavaScript work—query selectors, iteration, the tedious stuff developers hate.
quotes.fullText: I'm finding like, I'm chatting with chat GTP about this, of course. I'm like, they're doing a good job with the snippets because this is the vanilla JavaScript you can ever get. So it's giving me pretty good results about like how I should look for all of the elements and you know, those kind of like tedious things.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Queen using ChatGPT as a copilot for boilerplate JavaScript. Not writing the core logic herself (she understands the architecture), but delegating the tedious selector queries and DOM traversal to AI.

quotes.text: Explicit schema documentation for inputs with validation rules should become standard practice for all APIs.
quotes.fullText: The validation of the data is more transparent because then it's easier to kind of know what you wanna put in.
quotes.title: Hungover & Excited About Location Audio
quotes.context: Queen highlighting that MCP servers' explicit schema documentation for inputs (with validation rules) should become standard practice for regular REST APIs too. This transparency helps both AI clients and human developers understand expected data formats.

quotes.text: AI-as-scaffolding solves real repetitive work. Adding 50th title field manually is the exact use case for AI agents.
quotes.fullText: I see a lot of the freelancer and, and agencies are using the MCP server to kind of scaffold out. Um, the content structure of the site and mm-hmm. You know, having to go into Webflow CMS or framer CMS and be like, add field text, add field, like how many times have you added title and subtitle and hero image and it's just the pain, right?
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen observing how freelancers use MCP to scaffold CMS structures. Adding the 50th title-subtitle-image field is exactly what repetitive task automation should solve.

quotes.text: How do you balance making tools extendable while not overwhelming beginners or preventing misuse?
quotes.fullText: What is the trade off between being extendable but not making it hard for beginners or like putting in the gates, you know, so people don't do crazy stuff? And what if they like imported five times? You know, I don't want my store to be initialized a million times in case they use it inappropriately or like in a way that they shouldn't.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: Queen grapples with the classic library design tension: how to prevent misuse while keeping the API accessible to less experienced developers. Managing edge cases like multiple imports or inappropriate usage patterns.

quotes.text: Framer has really understood and made the component-driven approach work. You drag and drop, add a little code with code overrides, and custom components render right on the canvas.
quotes.fullText: It's just a completely different paradigm in thinking about building websites. They've really taken, I feel like they really understood and actually made the component-driven approach. You create a site with components and with Framer it's all components. It looks great on the screen. You drag and drop. You can add a little code with what they call code overrides. And then you can create custom components that you can throw on the canvas and then they render on the canvas. It's mind blowing. I don't understand how it can even work.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen genuinely impressed by Framer's developer experience. The ability to build custom React components that render live on a visual canvas represents a new paradigm she hasn't seen executed this well.

quotes.text: If you self-host Pruner Follows, you have to create accounts with the tools we used — that's a much better marketing asset than a demo.
quotes.fullText: This is much better for the dev tools because if you have to use Pruner Follows, you will actually have to make an account with Sata or whatever other tool that hopefully will sponsor us. So it'll actually get you much more into their services. It's a much better marketing asset if you actually go and download, self-host and create an account with the tools that we've used. And I've never seen anyone really do that. I've mostly seen it with demos, you know, like examples, but then you kind of already want to use the tool.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen inventing a new marketing model: free self-hosted tools that require signing up for the sponsoring services to run. Unlike demos (where you already want the tool), this catches people earlier in the journey — they want to use Pruner Follows, and the setup process naturally onboards them onto the underlying dev tools.

quotes.text: I've had lots of exploratory demos created as answers to support questions — they're living in CodeSandbox but nobody knows about them except that one person who got the link.
quotes.fullText: For Outseta, I've had lots of exploratory demos that I've kind of created as an answer to support questions. So we get support questions in, and then I have to figure out how our system works and I create little demos and then they are living there in CodeSandbox, but nobody knows about them except for that one person that got the link because it showcased their problem. So I'm like, I'm hoping to kind of clear a lot of those that could be helpful for more than one person and get those out so that they are available in our knowledge base.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen identifying a hidden content asset: support-driven demos sitting in CodeSandbox, each solving a real customer problem but only visible to one person. Publishing these to the knowledge base turns reactive support into proactive documentation.

quotes.text: Stripe and Supabase have LLM versions of their docs. Convex iteratively tested that AI gives consistent answers from their context documents.
quotes.fullText: Stripe and Supabase have like an LLM version of their docs. And then I've also seen some other providers have worked pretty hard on creating really good initial context documentation. One of them had a very thorough iterative process where it was like testing that the AI actually gave the same results again and again. And if it didn't, they fixed the document. They've been working on it so that it prompts the AI to come with a similar answer every time.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen surveying the emerging practice of LLM-optimized documentation. Companies are now testing their docs against AI models for consistency—a new form of documentation QA where the 'user' is an LLM, not a human reader.

quotes.text: Sometimes the best productivity hack is admitting you're in a scattered phase and just riding the wave.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about accepting natural productivity cycles

quotes.text: QR codes are now ubiquitous. Combined with family's excitement about audio guides, timing is finally right for revival.
quotes.fullText: But it came back now because we were, so we were out walking in the botanical gardens, the whole family, and they had these glass things with stuffed animals inside of them. And there was no information. They were just like standing there. And my daughter was like, oh, what is that? And then kind of that idea came back and I was like, now everybody knows what the QR code was. So is there a QR code on this thing with like headphones or something? Somebody would realize, oh, I can just QR code it and there will be some audio for me here.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: The botanical gardens moment catalyzed the realization that QR code ubiquity finally removes the discovery/usability barrier that killed the project years ago.

quotes.text: If you plan a focus session, do the prep ahead of time — get your coffee, open the GitHub, check the issue. When you sit down, all you have to do is code.
quotes.fullText: If you plan a focus session, usually an hour and a half, you need to do the prep ahead of time. Get your coffee, your snacks if you need it. And if it's something coding related, then maybe do your research before that time. Like opening the GitHub and what was the issue. And asking people some questions — do all of that. So when you sit down for the one and a half hour, all you have to do is code, or all you have to do is write.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen sharing a focus technique from her coworking group's 'Fearless Leader Nurse': separate preparation from execution. The insight from the 12 Week Year book reinforces what she already knows but needs to be reminded of.

quotes.text: Audio-only format prevents screen distraction; on-location interviews are more engaging than office interviews about the same topics.
quotes.fullText: From all the things that we learned when we did this last time, with audio, you could still look at the things that you're around. You're not staring at a screen. We like really don't wanna encourage people looking at a screen while they're out and about. And that's one of the thing. And the other thing is if you interview the person at the spot, they will speak in a way that makes it more engaging because they will talk about the things they see around them. You're standing in the same spot. So it becomes more engaging than if you go to their office and you interview them about the same thing.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen extracting specific learnings from the 2016 audio guide project. Audio-only preserves situational awareness and on-location interviews naturally capture more authentic storytelling.

quotes.text: Flat file markdown systems like Obsidian are becoming the way if you wanna power up with AI. You own the files and you can have them on your computer.
quotes.fullText: I think, and it's as seen Obsidian that we talked about before, which is a flat file, um, knowledge kind of base... Suddenly that is becoming, you know, I think it was always a good ethos, but now it's like, that's the way if you wanna use, you know, if you wanna power up with AI. Um, you own the files and you can have them on your computer.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Flat-file markdown systems like Obsidian are having a revival because they work perfectly with AI agents. The 'files first' philosophy is being validated by the new paradigm.

quotes.text: A lot of people are surprised at how fully featured Outseta is—email, helpdesk, membership—compared to what Webflow bolted on.
quotes.fullText: Webflow has announced that they are going to be cutting their membership feature. There are a lot of people reaching out and asking questions and a lot of people being surprised at how fully featured you get, a more full product from Outseta. So you can get your email and your help desk and everything connected to just selling the membership. People are surprised, but it's going to be, because this is a substantial feature. People are going to be pissed. But I do think when they explore Outseta and the other alternatives, they'll find something that fits them even better and that's focused on exactly that. It's not just adding it on top of a site builder.
quotes.title: Webflow Cuts Memberships, Let It Snow & Shipping the Imperfect Feature
quotes.context: Webflow announced they're cutting their membership/e-commerce feature with a 12-month grace period. Queen sees this as a major Outseta opportunity—displaced Webflow users are discovering Outseta is a dedicated membership operating system, not a bolt-on feature. The long deadline means planning time for demos and migration tooling.

quotes.text: The gap between 'this should be simple' and 'why is this taking three weeks' is where real product experience lives.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about product development complexity

quotes.text: My ideas come from talking, surprise, surprise. I need to talk through my ideas, not just write them down on paper.
quotes.fullText: I realized, which is not a surprise, my ideas come from talking, surprise, surprise. But I realized that more and more lately. So I'm like, I need to talk through my ideas, not just write them down on paper.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen explicitly naming her creative process: ideas emerge through conversation, not written planning. This self-awareness directly informs her service design — if she works best this way, her clients might too.

quotes.text: When designers use Figma properly—thinking in components, systems, flexbox—they're already mentally coding. The jump to actual CSS is surprisingly short.
quotes.fullText: When you're using Figma properly, you're very close to coding. Mentally. You know, you're thinking in components, your thinking in systems, you are kind of doing all of the things that a frontend developer would do. With James, our designer at Outseta, he started out in Figma, then started doing Webflow sites for people. And Webflow has a lot of the same tools as Figma, but you're basically using Flexbox. And then when he started seeing the bridge between what he was setting in Figma and then Webflow, suddenly the jump to CSS was very short. He's been working a lot under the hood in Outseta admin, just cleaning up inconsistencies that developers have kind of left. And with AI and his knowledge from Figma and Webflow, he's getting a lot of stuff done.
quotes.title: Unfocused, Redesigns & Row Level Security Pain
quotes.context: Queen mapping the designer-to-developer pipeline she's seen with James at Outseta: Figma (visual components) → Webflow (visual + CSS) → actual CSS → production code fixes. AI accelerates the last mile. This is the exact user journey Galleon Gateway targets.

quotes.text: Self-awareness: "I am a deadline kind of person"—this shapes how you structure work, from building challenges (20 videos in 4 days) to accepting your own productivity patterns.
quotes.fullText: You mean slow and steady? Um, but I was gonna say, if anybody has an idea for like a mini SaaS, like a one feature SaaS that I could make, I would love, um, to hear ideas.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Understanding your own work style is crucial to sustainable productivity and avoiding burnout.

quotes.text: Framer competing up there with Webflow was interesting—not making something for a ghost town, but for a platform with real traction.
quotes.fullText: Having Framer, which is still relatively a newcomer kind of compete up there with Webflow was interesting. Like they're really coming in hot and um, yeah. So that was like, okay, got that little motivation I needed that there will be people seeing and using, uh, this and um, you know, and not just like making something for a ghost town of framer.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Understanding market adoption is crucial for deciding where to invest engineering effort.

quotes.text: Design products intentionally small enough for family to maintain. If customers need more, they migrate to larger competitors—that's okay.
quotes.fullText: I realize I need multiple projects. And if people need more, they will have to migrate off of us to keep it in the shape and the size that we can sustain, you know, so it's sustainable for us as a family. That is another longer ramble for me, but that's what I've been thinking about. Family product fit.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen explicitly rejecting the growth treadmill. She's designing for customer churn as features and needs exceed what she wants to build—and she's at peace with that.

quotes.text: Security isn't just about protecting data; it's about protecting the trust your users place in your vibe-coded weekend project.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about security responsibility

quotes.text: I always put a date on my quotes — valid for seven days, and if I don't hear back, I'll contact you on this date. I forgot this time and now I'm stuck.
quotes.fullText: I always put a date on it. I'll be like, this is valid for seven days or 14 days. And then I also say, if I don't hear back, I'll contact you and then I'll put a date on when I will contact you. Because then you lay down the expectation that you will follow up. And also that this quote is not valid forever. And I forgot to do this this time, and now I'm like, when should I email them?
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen sharing a practical sales process mistake. Expiration dates on quotes serve double duty: they create natural follow-up moments and signal scarcity. Without them, you lose the excuse to re-engage.

quotes.text: Getting up off the desk is good for business. It's not procrastinating. You need to fold some clothes, walk around the neighborhood, and let it churn in the back of your head.
quotes.fullText: Life is just so much nicer when you get up off the desk and actually making that like, this is good for business, this is good for the code or whatever. It's not me procrastinating. It's like you need to get up, maybe fold some clothes, walk around the neighborhood to do something else and just let it churn in the back of your head.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen reframing breaks from self-indulgence to business strategy. The insight that stepping away isn't procrastination but an active part of the creative and technical process.

quotes.text: Make created a webhook endpoint in Stripe for me, attached a scenario, and I had a failed payment SMS flow done in an hour. I would not have coded that in an hour.
quotes.fullText: I had a Stripe event listener done in less than a minute. Make will actually create a webhook endpoint in Stripe for you, and then create a scenario attached to that for you. And you can just click. You just select what events you wanna listen to. And then it was little boop, boop, boop, little circles of things that can happen and little filters. So like, oh, if this event is the fourth event, let's do this. And I was just like, this is insane. The whole thing was done in an hour. I would not have coded that in an hour, let me tell you that.
quotes.title: Slow & Steady Really Is the Way — Framer Plugin Launch & the Power of Breaks
quotes.context: Queen's conversion moment with no-code tools. As a developer she had been dismissing Make, but experiencing the speed of setting up Stripe webhook listeners and conditional flows changed her mind.

quotes.text: When we're at the cabin, we work in the mornings, three to four hours, and then do vacation afterwards.
quotes.fullText: We usually, when we're here at the cabin office as we call it, or on our vacation, we usually work in the mornings, so try to get in 3, 4 hours in the morning and then do vacation afterwards, which is a pretty good, pretty sweet deal actually.
quotes.title: Bittersweet Summer, Nursing Home Move & Glue Code
quotes.context: Queen describing the family's summer work-life integration pattern: mornings for work at the cabin, afternoons for vacation. Not fully off, not fully on. A practical implementation of 'family product fit' that lets the business keep moving while the family actually rests.

quotes.text: AI clients break when you use 'page number' for offsets instead of record counts—terminology matters for AI understanding.
quotes.fullText: Our offset is 1, 2, 3, 4, 5... page numbers... but I also, I'm used to the newer best practices to use the number of records... when I call it page number, we're all good.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen highlighting a critical API design insight: terminology that's fine for human developers confuses AI clients. 'Offset' should mean record offset (0, 100, 200), not page number (1, 2, 3). AI models have strong priors about API conventions.

quotes.text: Developers end up doing carpentry, cooking, or sourdough because our work never gives the same tactile feedback as seeing physical results.
quotes.fullText: I think that's why a lot of developers end up starting to do carpentry or cooking or sourdough bread or like, they get these very hands-on type hobbies because the work we do, even when it's like immediate solutions, it's still not visible in the same way. It doesn't have the same tactile feedback where you know, I did this and also I did this, and it's done for, you know, and it doesn't have to be done until two to three years down the road.
quotes.title: Thankful, Power Washing & Two-Factor Authentication
quotes.context: Queen connecting her power washing meditation to a broader pattern: developers gravitating toward physical hobbies with visible, permanent results. Software is never done and progress is invisible. Power washing, carpentry, sourdough all provide what coding cannot: tangible, lasting evidence of your effort.

quotes.text: I need more like whimsy and joy this year. There's just needs to be a little bit more.
quotes.fullText: I did my business a yearly planning group thing and the only thing I got down from that day, um, was like, I need more like whimsy and joy this year. There's just needs to be a little bit more. Glede as we say in Norwegian.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Queen's one clear takeaway from her annual planning session—the need to explicitly build joy and playfulness into the work. 'Glede' is untranslatable but means a particular kind of spontaneous delight. This sets the emotional tone for the episode.

quotes.text: When I have the bike, the city feels so small. I can go anywhere in 15 minutes and I just become more spontaneous.
quotes.fullText: When I have it, I feel, it feels so small. Like I can go anywhere in the city on 15 minutes with a bike and I just become more spontaneous. Because I don't have to think about public transport or if I had a car like parking, it's just such a freedom.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Queen articulating the emotional value proposition of the e-bike: it's not about transport, it's about spontaneity and perceived city size. When the bike breaks, the city feels huge again. This is the feeling the company is named after: We.

quotes.text: I need to be mindful that I need these things on a regular schedule, because it's easy to forget in the everyday grind and then you start feeling a little off.
quotes.fullText: I'm going to try and do that again in February. I just like me mindful that I need these things on our regular schedule because I do think it's easy to forget like in the everyday grind and then you start feeling a little off or you're feeling a little you know well you don't even notice it yourself often that you're like a little bit like grumpy or whatever.
quotes.title: Year in Review: Rest, Recovery, and Recalibration
quotes.context: Queen learning through experience that social connection needs structural scheduling or it gets squeezed out. This becomes a core 2025 commitment.

quotes.text: I don't do unpaid open source anymore.
quotes.fullText: Yeah, yeah, yeah. It was paid. Don't do, I don't do unpaid open source anymore.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Queen's firm boundary on open source work, stated matter-of-factly when discussing the Cloudinary transformer update. Three years into occasional paid contributions triggered by large client requests. A clear identity position: open source contribution is professional work deserving compensation.

quotes.text: Fall has the vibe of cleaning up dependencies and doing chore tasks that don't require hard mental work.
quotes.fullText: I feel like fall has that vibe where it's like, take a chill and do some tasks that are not hard mental work, but just need to be done. And you have more time to just sit on the computer, you don't want to go out as much. You can spend a night cleaning some dependencies. Since coding is both hobby and work, it's one of those things you can just do, especially those tasks that don't require as much mental energy.
quotes.title: Open Source Aging, No-Code Speed & The Perception Gap
quotes.context: Queen articulating seasonal work rhythms: fall for cleanup chores, winter for focused deep work, spring for energy and socializing. Matches her advocacy for working with natural rhythms rather than against them.

quotes.text: Create a library of feature tips that can be repurposed - high initial investment but very small investment after that.
quotes.fullText: Yeah. It's like a, it's a high kind of initial investment. But then it's, it's a very small investment. Like if you have 20 of them, that's all you need to start. And then whenever you have a new thing that's being announced, you add it to the library and it will just keep on growing. And then maybe once a year you, you'd look at like, what are some features people aren't using that they should be using? And then you add another five or 10.
quotes.title: Thankful & Focused: Lillian's Filmmaking, AI for Brownfield Code, and the Pipeline Problem
quotes.context: Scalable content strategy for ongoing feature discovery

quotes.text: Create a shared fiction that solves everyone's real needs—daughter maintains independence, you get forced morning movement.
quotes.fullText: I realized I just have to do it in the morning. So I, you know, I walk, um, my daughter to the bus, which is our family. Um, what's it like. It's a like known life lie. We have a word for this in Norwegian where like everybody in our family knows that she can get there herself, but we pretend I have to walk her to the bus station so that it's like I will start my day. Yeah, yeah. But it's, it's so that I get out of bed and I get my day started and we're all, we're all in on this. Pretending, uh, because she, you know, she can get home from like extracurricular activities. She takes the bus all over town. Like she doesn't need me to walk her to the bus station in the morning. Um, but I do.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen describing a brilliant family hack: create a shared fiction that solves everyone's real needs. The daughter maintains independence and can travel independently; Queen gets forced morning movement before deep work pulls her in. Structure wellness through mutual pretense.

quotes.text: Quick start for fastest path, expansion for more WeWeb-y approach, then third that's even more WeWeb-y. You can expand without hindering that expansion in a way that makes it harder.
quotes.fullText: I came up with a new approach that has been simmering in my brain where I can give them a quick start - the fastest way to get some authentication on their WeWeb app with Outseta. And then I give them an expansion article on how to do it more the WeWeb way, and then a third one that is even more WeWeb-y so they can get started really fast, but in a way that isn't hindering that expansion, because you can do it in a way that makes that expansion harder.
quotes.title: Support Load Patterns, WeWeb+Outseta Guides, and Rethinking Redesigns
quotes.context: Queen's strategy for addressing different user sophistication levels with non-blocking progression paths

quotes.text: We're seeing ChatGPT show up as a referrer for signups—people search for business tooling conversationally and Outseta covers more of their needs.
quotes.fullText: We're seeing a lot of signups coming from ChatGPT as the referrer. The hypothesis is a little bit that Outseta has been around for a long time and we solve that cross section of needs. The answers that Jeff has gotten is like they have been solving for like business tooling or like broader, you know, if you Google, you search for like email or billing, you're very specific in what you need, but when you're chatting with ChatGPT, it's more like, oh, I'm starting a business. Like what do I need? And Outseta solves a lot of them.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen identifying a new acquisition dynamic: ChatGPT users ask broader questions than Google searchers. This favors all-in-one tools like Outseta over specialized tools, because conversational AI recommends solutions to broad problems, not narrow searches.

quotes.text: Instead of replacing me in the interview, give me an AI guide that listens in, tracks which questions I've covered, and tells me to shut up when I talk too much.
quotes.fullText: Between what we were talking about and where we're at now, you could make something like that for me where it says just like, shut up, shut up, shut up, shut up. And then like now talk and then prompt me with my next possible three questions. Because I've done and I've managed to actually not talk in some of these interviews, but I have a hard time. You have that sheet and it's like, you know, which question should I put in now? I have a sheet in front of me and then I get so hung up on that that I forget to listen.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen designing an AI user interview assistant in real time. Not a replacement for the human interviewer, but an augmentation: tracking coverage, prompting next questions, and literally telling her to be quiet. She acknowledges her own bias problem — she gets excited and starts talking — and wants AI to compensate for it.

quotes.text: A lot of the work we do building products is more of a creative process than an engineering factory. If you never allow unfocused time, it'll burn you out.
quotes.fullText: I feel like a lot of the work we do with building products, it's more of a creative process than an engineering factory. Like if you work as an engineer like I did at the bank, this is your feature, do it, next feature, do it. But when you're working on a product or you're part of a startup, a lot of it is like, what should we work on? What is the next priority? Should we even code this? If you're then sitting and collecting little articles and reading, that might be a good thing because you're not building unneeded stuff just to fill your nine to five.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen distinguishing between factory-mode engineering (feature assembly line) and product-building (creative, exploratory). In product work, the thinking and wandering IS productive work. Building without thinking creates maintenance debt.

quotes.text: Structure pricing around upfront project funding cycles, which Norwegian cultural projects understand—covering multi-year hosting in one payment.
quotes.fullText: I think if we go for the regional market first and we really make it so that they can pay for it in a way that makes sense for these projects that are usually funded by funds or like project funds and we kind of understand that cycle, then we could be a better player than potential competitors from other countries that kind of don't have that local knowledge about how these guys would wanna pay.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen identifying local knowledge advantage: Norwegian cultural funding only funds creation, not operations. She plans to align pricing with this reality (upfront multi-year payments).

quotes.text: Where will the people we need at the senior level get their experience if they can never be junior researchers or junior developers?
quotes.fullText: But what I'm wondering is like, where will these, cause what you're saying is like, okay, you can get the AI to do a lot of the basic, like they're a decent researcher. But they're not like a really good researcher. Where will the people we need at the senior level get their experience? Like if they can never be junior researchers or like junior developers, because like that can be, you know, junior dev stuff can be done by no-code tools and junior researching can be done by AI, like how will people kind of gain the skill level that we need to have?
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen raising a profound structural question about AI's impact on professional development. If AI handles junior-level work, and no-code handles junior-level coding, where does the next generation of senior practitioners come from? This is the pipeline problem nobody is answering.

quotes.text: Getting AI to create project documents means I think about things more thoroughly before implementing—I see the full plan and can spot what's wrong.
quotes.fullText: What I found now with like asking it to kind of create project documents and outlines, and that part is that I also get to think about things more thoroughly before implementing. Like some of these things I wouldn't have thought about before starting to implement. And being like, oh yeah, but when you see like a full plan with like, it even gave me like database table structure suggestions. And then I'm like, well, that's probably how I would've done it. But now that I see it all, like written out and in context, it's like, hmm, you know, maybe we don't wanna do it that way.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen realizing that AI-generated planning documents serve as a thinking tool. Seeing your own assumptions written out in context reveals flaws you'd never catch while coding. The plan becomes a design review before code exists.

quotes.text: Launches force you to be disciplined about having something new that's ready and clearly defined.
quotes.fullText: What it does is it forces you to be a little bit disciplined about we have something new and it is now ready and here is the information about that thing that we are putting on Product Hunt.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen distinguishing between the actual customer acquisition value of Product Hunt (minimal) and its real value: forcing a clear narrative and defined moment for a milestone. It's about clarity and marketing discipline, not virality.

quotes.text: Ten weeks of morning walks create a daily anchor in basic gratitude—greeting neighbors, watching the sun rise, appreciating the foundation.
quotes.fullText: I'm on my 10th week and I walk around the neighborhood every morning and it usually ends up with me just being super grateful for like the basic like basis layer of my life. You know? There's always gonna be shit happening, but I walk around, I greet with my neighbors. The sun usually comes up. There's a little bit of nature. There's houses. It's a good life.
quotes.title: New Year Gratitude & Framing Perception
quotes.context: Queen's daily gratitude practice (10 weeks of morning walks) grounding her in foundational appreciation. Not denying challenges, but anchoring in what's reliable and good. Simple, sustainable practice.

quotes.text: Be in a position to apply for TinySeed in February 2026—not because we have to apply, but because having that goal forces systematic thinking.
quotes.fullText: Be in a position to apply for TinySeed in February, 2026. And the thing with that, it's like, it doesn't have, like, we might not have to apply or like, we might not want to apply. But I just wanna be in that position that have a goal that makes you think more systematically and more organized. And also maybe in a future scenario, build it so that it could be sold. And that's because I've heard this advice that if you build it like that, it's easier to run.
quotes.title: Gateway Goals, Sailing Countdown & Claude Writes Better Docs
quotes.context: Queen using TinySeed application readiness as a North Star—not necessarily to apply, but because the discipline of being investor-ready forces better product and business decisions. Building to be sellable makes it easier to run.

quotes.text: Most business-to-business software that is quite expensive to run needs large customers at some point. You either say no or you do it -- halfway doesn't work.
quotes.fullText: I think most business to business software that is quite expensive to run needs large customers at some point. Maybe I'm wrong. But it's a hard transition or it's, you gotta either say no or you gotta do it. It's a very hard thing to do halfway.
quotes.title: Shai Schechter on Exiting Right Message, Feeling Your Feelings & Life After SaaS
quotes.context: Queen articulating a pattern she's observed across the SaaS ecosystem: B2B tools eventually need enterprise customers to sustain themselves. The transition to enterprise sales is binary -- you commit or you don't. Half-measures create more problems.

quotes.text: Show summer-only customers the waiting list length so they realize they might not get a bike back if they cancel.
quotes.fullText: That is actually a clip because we've been talking about churn reduction campaigns, and I don't think we've touched on that. I'm gonna bring that back to the team on Monday because that is valid. Like we hope to be able to buy a lot more bikes, but the waiting list just keeps getting longer and longer. So it's absolutely true that they might come back in April and there are no bikes for them to rent.
quotes.title: Bike Leasing, Stripe Shenanigans & Slow Progress
quotes.context: Benedikt suggested showing the waiting list to churning customers. Queen immediately recognized this as actionable and planned to bring it to the team meeting. The insight: transparency about scarcity is a legitimate churn reduction tool. If customers see 100 people waiting, they'll think twice about giving up their spot.

quotes.text: Use a dedicated focus planner for each side project—don't spend time researching the tool, just dump your thoughts.
quotes.fullText: The mountain code is 'use a map and compass, always know where you are.' And I translated that into 'record your progress, always know where you are.' What I've learned from my business group Creative Fierce is to have a notebook that is called a focus planner that you use for one focus project so that whenever you work on that focus project, you take that planner out and you work on that. I said, you know, it could be whatever, but do not spend time researching the tool because that is not the point—you just need to dump these thoughts.
quotes.title: Feeling Free, Lovely Everyday Life & Side Project Code
quotes.context: Queen translating the Norwegian Mountain Code rule about maps and compasses into a side project principle. Diana on Twitter immediately applied it by creating a focus.md in her repo. The key: the tool doesn't matter, the practice of recording does.

quotes.text: Understanding the technical benefits of magic link auth isn't the same as liking the user experience.
quotes.fullText: I see, I kind of see that the beauty from like the provider or from the service... but as a user, I hate it so much.
quotes.title: Hungover & Excited About Location Audio
quotes.context: Queen observing that while she understands the technical benefits of magic link authentication (allowing platform switching without password migration), she hates the user experience. This sets up her later insight about using AI to overcome procrastination in sales outreach.

quotes.text: We could have a baby book for your SaaS with milestones — even celebrating your first support ticket, because it means people care.
quotes.fullText: We could have these milestones and since we have usually the whole business in Outseta, like we'll know how many people they have on newsletter lists, we'll know how many support tickets they have and what they've made and all of that. We could have a little fun baby book for your startup. Because there's not all SaaS, but like a baby book for your business.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen pitching a gamification/celebration concept for Outseta: pull data from the platform to create shareable milestone badges. First support ticket, first chargeback win, etc. Doubles as brand visibility since Outseta is typically white-label.

quotes.text: There are fewer jobs for young teenagers now—I wonder if it takes them longer to learn these sales and customer service lessons.
quotes.fullText: I was told these things by the manager at one of the first stores I worked at and then all the way up to running businesses now, but I thought about these kids. Because there's fewer jobs for them, proper jobs, at that age bracket. So I don't know if it's gonna take them longer to learn some of these lessons or not.
quotes.title: Bike Inventory Puzzles, 2FA Edge Cases & Lemonade Stand Economics
quotes.context: Queen reflecting on how her own customer service skills were shaped by early retail jobs where managers corrected her behavior. Wondering whether kids today, with fewer entry-level jobs available, will take longer to develop these interpersonal business skills.

quotes.text: Have a branded URL that redirects to jsDelivr, so you can move to something else without making customers update anything.
quotes.fullText: Before I looked at how the others did it, that was one of the solutions I had in my mind. We can just forward, we'll have scripts.outseta.com or something and forward to jsDelivr and just replicate the URL paths that jsDelivr has and then just pass it through.
quotes.title: Tech Situationship, Sailing Dreams & Script Versioning Strategy
quotes.context: Queen arriving at the same conclusion Benedikt advises: own the customer-facing URL layer even when using a third-party CDN. This gives you vendor independence — if jsDelivr goes down, you redirect rather than asking all customers to update script tags.

quotes.text: If we as service providers add a semantic layer—vector search, thematic extraction—AI agents won't burn all the user's tokens downloading everything.
quotes.fullText: What it would do would be like, go through, download them all, look through them all, and use up all of the user's tokens. But if we as service providers can provide a layer on top of our content with some vector search and some thematic extraction—we run a little AI on our side that could pull out themes. One of the things that makes Open Claw seem so amazing is that it has this concept of memory, like it writes down what it's done every day. And that is fed into different systems for surfacing the themes and the decisions. So for a tool like Outseta, there's an untapped potential where we're sitting on the content and if we can enable the AI to search through it without having to do all of the processing themselves.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen proposing a novel MCP enhancement: instead of forcing AI agents to download and process all emails/content (burning user tokens), SaaS providers should add a semantic layer—vector search, thematic extraction—that lets AI quickly find relevant content. Inspired by Open Claw's memory system.

quotes.text: Our operations guy says if he texts them, they answer right away. And the answer is usually yes, I want the bike. But they didn't open the email.
quotes.fullText: We're still seeing on the waiting list for instance like there's a 40 percent open rate. And then our operations guy was like, if I text them, they answer right away. And the answer is usually, yes, I want the bike, but they didn't open the email. And it makes sense. If you look at the demographic and where they're at in life, they're probably have pretty stressful jobs with a lot of email as well. So I was like, okay, we need SMS.
quotes.title: Energized, Building Data Trust & A Lovely Everyday Life
quotes.context: Queen discovering that email isn't the right channel for Whee's customer demographic — busy parents with overflowing inboxes. SMS gets immediate responses with positive intent. Adapting communication strategy to match customer reality.

quotes.text: With no-code tools and AI coding, the only code left to write is glue code: the integrations between systems.
quotes.fullText: I was just like, are we entering the real age of glue code? Like the code, the only code you need to build is like the glue code. And then I thought back to all of the things that we've done. It's always, always been in the integration space. So I, you know, we kind of lost our Gatsby specialization a while back. I thought like, maybe just integrations or these integration apps, maybe that could be a little bit of a specialization one could focus on.
quotes.title: Bittersweet Summer, Nursing Home Move & Glue Code
quotes.context: Queen connecting multiple observations: Canva launching apps, her Framer plugin work, Webflow apps, Zapier integrations. The insight is that as no-code and AI handle more of the core product code, the remaining human-written code is the glue between systems. She recognizes her career has always been in this integration space and wonders if it could be a deliberate specialization.

quotes.text: Some founders are discovering and building features that AI told users about, creating an interesting dynamic where support requests drive product.
quotes.fullText: I see a lot of people chatting about making features that AI says they have. The guys from Leave Me Alone app—James was writing on Twitter that this new hobby is like asking ChatGPT what features Leave Me Alone has, and then making those features because they've been getting through support. They're like, you know, where's the feature? And they're like, this feature, we've never had this feature.
quotes.title: AI Context, MCP Servers, and Summer Travels
quotes.context: Queen observing an emerging pattern: users ask AI what features a product has, AI hallucinates features, users ask support about them, and founders build those features to reduce support load. It's a strange feedback loop but potentially effective.

quotes.text: Webflow users pay for cookie banners with an X button on them—there's definite willingness to pay for small UI wins.
quotes.fullText: But then it's like, well, in the Webflow world, they pay for cookie banners that has an X on them.
quotes.title: Battered but Building Gateway
quotes.context: Queen validating that the Webflow market has proven willingness to pay for relatively simple solutions. If people pay for basic cookie banners, they'll pay for interactive data fetching capabilities. Market demand signal.

quotes.text: I used the Descript cleanup and the first edit was a perfect edit from what I gave it. It removes retakes, removes rambling.
quotes.fullText: I recorded a video, I made like a medium style gating demo. I made a video for that, which wasn't really good. But I was using Descript. I just like rambled on. I used the Descript cleanup and make sense of this. And it did really well. And it kind of got me started thinking like how I should do these types of videos. The first edit was, from what I gave it, a perfect edit. So I'm gonna keep doing that.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: Queen finding that Descript's AI cleanup transforms rambling screen recordings into clean videos. The tool lowers the bar for creating content enough that she'll actually do it consistently instead of procrastinating on perfect takes.

quotes.text: Galleon Attributes is now live with GET requests and data attribute binding for Webflow. It's an open-source entry point to the Gateway ecosystem.
quotes.fullText: The first version of Galleon Attributes is now live. It's only GET requests at this point, but you can get data and you can bind data just using data attributes in Webflow. I'm pretty happy with how it turned out. I hope that it can become a fun open source project that Webflow folks can use. And that could also be a gateway to Galleon Gateway. Because there inevitably the question will come up, like how do I exchange this token for that token? And it's like, well, you could do it with all this code, or I have this little service over here that you could pay for.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen describing her product launch strategy: Galleon Attributes as the free, open-source entry point that naturally funnels advanced users toward the paid Galleon Gateway service.

quotes.text: I went through all the signups from the last 30 days to figure out what tech they're using—discovering Framer was the second-most used after Webflow provided the validation I needed.
quotes.fullText: We don't really have that good tracking of what accounts are using, what technology, so sometimes it can feel a little discouraging to be like, okay, I'm gonna upgrade this plugin. Like, are anyone even using framer? So I just had like a brief energy spurt and I downloaded all of, um, or I went through all of the signups for the last 30 days that were still active so that then I can actually figure out what tech they are.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Taking time to analyze customer data reveals motivation and validates continued investment decisions.

quotes.text: I can build this—that's not the hard part at all. The goal is to reach 10 paying customers by focusing on marketing and activation over coding more features.
quotes.fullText: I also wrote like, by focusing on marketing and activation slash onboarding over coding more features. I realized when planning, what are some sub goals, sub projects? And I was like, I can build, like I'm so certain I can build this. But that's not the hard part with this project. That's not the part at all.
quotes.title: Gateway Goals, Sailing Countdown & Claude Writes Better Docs
quotes.context: Queen explicitly committing to marketing-first over feature-first for Galleon. The self-awareness is clear: building is her comfort zone, but marketing and activation are where the real challenge lies. Written down as a planning constraint.

quotes.text: Well-structured node scripts in GitHub repos are far more discoverable by AI than Code Sandbox demos.
quotes.fullText: It suddenly hit me that I could just do them as node scripts. So I started working on a repo then in GitHub because it seems to me that the AI loves reading GitHub repos. In some tools you can even hook up a repo as kind of a context source.
quotes.title: AI Context, MCP Servers, and Summer Travels
quotes.context: Queen had a breakthrough realizing that AI systems naturally crawl and understand GitHub repositories better than sandboxed code environments. This led her to shift from Code Sandbox to GitHub-based node script examples for demonstrating Outseta features.

quotes.text: When they told tech people they wanted to scale, they got advice for 10,000 users. But scale for us is 1,500 bikes in three years.
quotes.fullText: When they talk to tech people and they say scale, they said the word scale, and that's when they've gotten the advice that you need to move over to a proper database. But scale for us now, it's like 10,000 bikes. Airtable could easily run on Airtable. This is just not an issue. But if you tell somebody techie, oh, we wanna scale, as I told them, we're talking about a minimum of 10,000 customers, that's scale to a tech person. And here we're talking about a maximum of like 1,500 within the next three years.
quotes.title: Energized by Whee, Unfocused After Vacation & The Creative Process
quotes.context: Queen identifying a communication gap between startup founders and technical advisors: the word 'scale' triggers enterprise-grade recommendations from techies, but Whee's actual scale (330 to 1500 bikes) is well within Airtable's capabilities. The advice was solving the wrong problem.

quotes.text: The agent is putting in tables and adding demo content to databases while you build the feature, so you get real fake data in real time.
quotes.fullText: While he was creating a Outseta + Convex demo, you know, the agent was just off, like putting in the tables it needed and adding, adding, um, demo content to the databases so that he could see how it would look, uh, in that little CMS he was creating. That, and that is super beneficial. Like you're working on a thing and you are getting like real fake data being put into your database while you're building out the feature and you can like, see what's happening.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: The ideal use case: the agent handles routine plumbing (creating test data, setting up schemas) while the human stays in flow building the actual feature. This is where AI integration maximizes human productivity.

quotes.text: AI can discover undocumented API surface area—how do you manage breaking changes when the surface area keeps expanding?
quotes.fullText: Yeah. It's that like, if it's not documented, is it a feature? Or yeah. Can you like, pull it out from under them? Um, if it's, it wasn't documented, but, because I think that's gonna be more prevalent now with ai. Like the AI can read library code and like figure out how to do things that are not documented.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: A fundamental question about library maintenance in an AI-driven future. If AI can discover undocumented API surface area, how do you manage breaking changes? Traditional approaches assumed only intentional users would discover hidden features, but AI changes that calculus.

quotes.text: Building products requires building empathy. Understanding users—who they are, how they think, what they struggle with—is foundational.
quotes.fullText: So I'm learning more about the people getting, you know, the empathy and understand.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen articulating the foundational work of product building: deep empathy for who users are, how they think, what they struggle with. Can't be shortcuts.

quotes.text: Coworker mode is sandboxed to a folder. Permissions don't persist between sessions. It wouldn't even push to GitHub.
quotes.fullText: Coworker is mostly to work with your files on your computer and work as a coworker. I think it's really good and it's very sandboxed. You give it access to a folder and if it tries to access anything outside that folder, it asks you very explicitly. Those permissions don't persist between sessions. Even if you gave it access to your downloads folder in one session, it's not doing that again in the next session. And I tried to push something to GitHub from it, and it didn't want to.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen recommending Claude Desktop's coworker mode as a safe starting point for AI-cautious users like Benedikt. The sandboxing—folder-scoped access, non-persistent permissions, no git push—addresses exactly the fears that keep people from trying AI tools.

quotes.text: We have a place in our knowledge base called code snippets that just showcase very specific recipes — they don't need an article, just a heading and copy-paste code.
quotes.fullText: We have now a place in our knowledge base I would just call code snippets that just showcase very specific recipes for things. If you wanna do custom things that are in addition, like you have custom scripts. So they don't need much, they just need to be published with a heading and be like, for this case you can use this code, copy paste it from line five to line 20 and into your site and cross your fingers, it will work.
quotes.title: Sun-Kissed in Portugal, Outsourcing & Mystery Dev
quotes.context: Queen defining a lightweight documentation format: code snippet recipes that don't need full articles. Just a heading, context sentence, and copy-pasteable code. Low-effort to publish, high-value for developers who just need the answer.

quotes.text: Location-specific limits concurrent usage because people must physically be there—no 100K simultaneous listeners problem.
quotes.fullText: I really wanna start with location based audio guides because it's very niche. Like you have to be there. It's not like there's gonna be a hundred thousand people wanting to listen to this audio guide at that specific point. Of course they can send the QR code to somebody and then they can scan it and listen to it, but there's never gonna suddenly be a hundred thousand people listening to the same thing at the same time.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen recognizing location-based scarcity as a feature, not a bug. It fundamentally limits scalability problems while keeping infrastructure costs reasonable.

quotes.text: One hour of live streaming every other week, and my team creates a constant stream of social media posts from that hour for all the other days.
quotes.fullText: I call it Go Live with Queen Raae and it would be me talking to you, a dev tool founder that used to be an engineer probably. And we'll talk or live stream or have office hours. We'll figure out the format and what fits your dev tool and we'll do that one hour every other week. Then me and my team will create a constant stream of social media posts from that hour for all the other days.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen unveiling her new service: a low-commitment livestream package for dev tool founders. The pitch is founder-as-face-of-brand, with Queen facilitating and her team handling content creation from the raw stream.

quotes.text: Family integration isn't about perfect work-life balance, it's about honest conversations at dinner about why mommy was typing all weekend.
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about authentic family integration

quotes.text: There's a personality type that has to ask questions even if all the answers are on your website. They need that connection with the person before they buy.
quotes.fullText: You have this personality that has to ask questions. So even if you have all the answers on your website, and even if they could have been a self-serve customer, they just have to ask questions and double-check. I have now learned to not be annoyed and be like, it's on the website. Because that's not it — they're trying, I think what they need is that they want that connection with the person before they buy. So they do it by asking questions.
quotes.title: Migraines, Sales Anxiety & the Greenfield Trap
quotes.context: Queen challenging the common indie hacker complaint about customers asking questions that are answered on the pricing page. Drawing from two books (Four Tendencies and a sales book) to explain this as a personality type, not ignorance. The fix isn't bigger text — it's recognizing the human need for connection.

quotes.text: You don't know what the other person is telling their family. Suddenly you're on a podcast talking about losing money and their spouse is listening.
quotes.fullText: You don't know what the other person maybe is sharing with their family, for instance. And then suddenly you're on a podcast talking about how you're losing money every month and somebody's husband is listening or wife is listening and is like, say what now? This is not the story you've been telling me. So you're kind of sharing other people's secrets as well, if it feels like a secret.
quotes.title: Shai Schechter on Exiting Right Message, Feeling Your Feelings & Life After SaaS
quotes.context: Queen identifying a rarely discussed risk of building in public with a co-founder: your transparency might expose information your co-founder hasn't shared with their own family. The hidden social cost of radical openness.

quotes.text: Claude gets his own GitHub account so he can request reviews from me. And a Google Workspace account with shared calendars where I control visibility.
quotes.fullText: I have created a Google Workspace account for my Sean Claw Van Bot, which is his name in my Google workspace, and then he's gotten his own GitHub account. If Claude has his own GitHub account, he can actually request reviews from me and I will get that up in my reminders. And then I'll just share my personal calendar and my family calendar with it as another user. In my personal calendar, I can just put things on private and he won't see the private events, he would just see that I'm blocked for those time periods.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen's methodical approach to AI agent identity: separate GitHub (enables PR review workflows—solves GitHub's limitation that you can't request a review from yourself), separate Google Workspace (calendar sharing with privacy controls). Treating the AI as a team member with appropriate access levels.

quotes.text: We need to get more comfortable with just having hobbies. Knitters lose money, horse riders lose money — but nobody tells them to monetize it.
quotes.fullText: I think there is a room and we need to get more comfortable with that, with our AI overlords to just have hobbies. Like what are we going to do with our time? And just having a hobby and not monetize it is — and I find that hard because a lot of my hobbies is things that are very close to what I do for money. Like if you code something fun, it should, you know, it's business right away. But like learning to say that no, this is a hobby project. This is for relaxation, for those artistic needs that you might have. And just let it be a hobby.
quotes.title: Anxious, Nostalgic & Brian's AI Research Pivot
quotes.context: Queen articulating a philosophy about keeping hobbies pure. When your skills overlap with your profession, the pressure to monetize everything is immense. She uses knitting friends and horseback riding as examples of hobbies nobody expects to be profitable.

quotes.text: Product-founder fit is as important as product-market fit—the product must work for the founder's life, not just the market.
quotes.fullText: There wasn't this thing, it's still a thing, product market fit. Like you need a product that fits in the market, you know, somebody needs to want what you're making. But then people were talking about product founder fit, that is also important that it's a product that works for the founder, both for the founder's skillset, but also the life that the founder kind of wants, right? Because there is different SaaS that demand different things from you as a founder.
quotes.title: Tech Fatigue, Family Business Vision, and Location-Based Audio Guides
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that beyond market demand, founders need to choose products that align with their desired lifestyle and skill set. This sets up the family product fit concept.

quotes.text: I'm lurking in communities and answering questions to understand pain points—immersive participation builds product intuition better than assumptions.
quotes.fullText: I've had to learn framer, you know, I don't sit in framer every day and build websites for, for my clients, but I'm also lurking a lot in like the communities and trying to answer questions to kind of get to know like, where are the pain points?
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Understanding how users actually use tools is more valuable than assumptions—this informs product decisions.

quotes.text: After the January gauntlet, a 24-hour spa trip reset my brain completely. Next year I'm booking it for the first week of February.
quotes.fullText: I was just powering through, powering through, and we came out of it and I was like, oh, I'm so ready. But I was just so tired. But then I had this spa thing booked with two friends from way back when. So we went to spa midweek for 24 hours. I came out of that just super relaxed. Two and three days later I was just so energized and inspired. I redesigned MixPod. I created this really cool design. I had so much fun doing it and I don't really remember what happened the week and a half before this spa thing. I think I just reset my brain. So next year I'm just gonna book it for the first week of February. Because I know January is the way it is and I just couldn't get geared back up.
quotes.title: Energized, Under the Weather & UserList Breaks Even
quotes.context: Queen discovering that planned recovery isn't optional — it's the unlock. The spa didn't just relax her, it unlocked a creative burst (MixPod redesign, new energy). She's now engineering this into her annual calendar: January is chaos, first week of February is reset.

quotes.text: You could train with the AI where you can mess up before you do this on your kid.
quotes.fullText: That could also be a good thing where you train with the AI where you can like mess up before you do this on your kid. Which is like a lot of what us parents are trying to do to like, you know, not force solutions and not come in with our opinions, but like really get the child to understand their own needs. It sounds like I'm ridiculing it. I'm not. I just find it hard. But a little bit of AI training wouldn't hurt.
quotes.title: The Forties
quotes.context: After discussing Nonviolent Communication and Lewis's AI avatar training product (Geeky Medic spinoff), Queen connects the dots: AI role-play could help parents practice empathic responses before using them on their kids. Acknowledges she finds empathic language hard but is committed to learning.

quotes.text: Screencasts are documentation-style content; Shorts need different approaches—short-form, native to the platform, with voiceovers or text rather than landscape recordings.
quotes.fullText: There's different genres of video for sure, and, uh, sometimes you can use what you use in your documentation on your YouTube, like if people are really interested and they're looking for that information. But I don't think a screencast like, as you said, like as a landscape on like Google shorts. Nobody's gonna watch that as a short.
quotes.title: Tired But Taking Rest Intentionally
quotes.context: Understanding platform-native content formats is essential for effective distribution and audience engagement.

quotes.text: Three AI directions: enable operators to analyze their own data, enable vibe-coders to integrate us, and get AI engines to recommend us.
quotes.fullText: For our customers, our existing customers—enabling them to pull out the data and analyze the data themselves, but also maybe we in the MCP can have some ready-made tooling that will do that for them. Eventually maybe in the product. Second, enabling the vibe-coders who wanna have the MCP server and the skills and the agent files—these things are rapidly evolving, but having those things in place so that they can get to success faster. And third, getting the engines to recommend you. How do we talk about ourselves in the way that they will recommend us.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen laying out Outseta's comprehensive AI strategy. The unique angle: Outseta's all-in-one nature (billing, auth, email, support) means they sit on cross-domain data that AI agents could analyze holistically—a competitive advantage over point solutions.

quotes.text: When you're a bootstrapped founder, every feature decision is really asking: 'Is this worth three months of our runway?'
quotes.context: AI-generated quote about bootstrapped prioritization

quotes.text: We're at a place where we can actually continue doing things the way we've done it, but actually get the AI to do it the way we expect it to.
quotes.fullText: I think it's been slowly dawning on me 'cause I've been trying at several points a lot, especially since we've been getting so much support from vibe coders where I was just like, well, I can't help you 'cause like we will never get your tool to do what it needs. So we need to change, but now it seems like we're at a space, at a place where we can actually continue doing things a little bit the way we've done it, but actually get the AI to like, you know, do it the way we expect it to instead of the other way around.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: Major mindset shift: instead of adapting the product to work with AI limitations, AI has matured to the point where it can understand their requirements and implement them correctly. This unlocks new possibilities without forcing architectural changes.

quotes.text: Announce small improvements to signal momentum without adding technical debt—it's the sweet spot between perception and product health.
quotes.fullText: There's sometimes where then I think a lot of companies end up adding things that you don't really need. And then you have that heightened like maintenance burden of those features just so it can look like things are happening. So like announcing those little things so that people get a sense that things are moving forward without like adding big features that will end up crippling the product—that's just like a sweet spot. You get the same perception that things are happening and you're not like adding stuff you shouldn't be adding just to kind of get a launch.
