quotes.title: New Year Gratitude & Framing Perception
quotes.context: Queen reframing 'shipping' as communication rather than feature development. Mini launches let you signal progress without the maintenance burden and technical debt of unnecessary features.

quotes.text: If this award had happened last year during my mom's illness, I wouldn't have been able to use it. Now that I've rested, I can actually step out into the community with it.
quotes.fullText: I feel like it came at the right time because finally ready to kind of step out into the community in Oslo again. I've tried like every now and then during my mom's illness, but now that I've rested up, I feel like I've finally have kind of like rested up and wanna be more outgoing and meet more people. It's helpful that like all of Oslo's tech community on LinkedIn has seen my face plastered with the title. Because it just makes it easier to go out and talk to people and also makes it easier not to have to start at the level where they're like, do you even code? Which can happen.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen reflecting on how timing and energy states affect what you can do with external validation. The award is valuable now because she has emotional resources to leverage it.

quotes.text: We are not putting that on my machine. I'll test one of these hosted things, maybe in Europe as an added precaution.
quotes.fullText: I'm not installing that on my machine. We are not putting that on my machine. But I did recently do a full backup of the machine, just in case any of my AI exploration really... I'm gonna test one of these hosted things. There's been a lot popping up. Even Laravel Forge was like, you can run Open Claw through Laravel Forge. I was also like, maybe I want this to run in Europe, just as an added precaution.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen's security-conscious approach to autonomous AI: full machine backup before exploration, refusing to run Open Claw on her personal machine, preferring European hosting for data sovereignty. Also set up a service key instead of personal API key after learning about Anthropic blocking personal key usage.

quotes.text: Our break was typing. Now suddenly the AI is doing it, you're on Twitter or YouTube. Not a break.
quotes.fullText: Because it feels like we're doing less work, but as I was saying, like we're still doing the same amount of high level work. Our break was typing. 'cause like, just typing things out takes time. Even if you're really fast, it's those like little micro breaks. And now suddenly because the AI is doing it, you're on, I don't know, me at least on Twitter or YouTube or something like that. Not a break.
quotes.title: Whimsy, AI Breakthroughs & Burnout Awareness
quotes.context: The hidden cost of fast AI: typing used to provide natural breaks for cognitive processing. Now the AI works at speed that prevents breaks, and our default fallback (social media) isn't actually restorative.

quotes.text: When I ask Cursor to add a feature, it remembers to update the README too—sometimes it even writes the docs before implementing.
quotes.fullText: When I ask it to add functionality, it actually also remembers that there needs to be a documentation in the README for how to use this new functionality. And it's not, again, always spot on, but like I often forget, like, I'm so excited doing, making the feature that you forget to update the README, or sometimes it updates the README and then it implements the feature. Like, I feel like it's a lot of fun.
quotes.title: Impatient for Gateway & AI That Won't Listen
quotes.context: Queen noting how AI coding tools solve the perennial developer problem of documentation drift. Cursor automatically maintains docs alongside feature implementation—sometimes even writing docs first, which is the ideal workflow most developers aspire to but rarely achieve.

quotes.text: With MCP servers, you can ask for three plans and have them created automatically instead of clicking through everything.
quotes.fullText: If you are a user of Outseta that do this, do this for clients... you could go into the chat interface and be like, make me three plans, and then say something about the plans, and then it goes off and creates those plans... you don't have to like click through everything yourself.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen recognizing that MCP servers solve a specific scaling problem for agencies: fast data entry and setup without manual UI clicking. Not for individual power users, but for those managing multiple client accounts.

quotes.text: Testing new patterns in contained environments before releasing broadly—Framer overrides first, not the reactive store.
quotes.fullText: And since Framer is like one of our growing customer basis. Like I, I thought it would be good to actually take a stab at making, so that part isn't offic like the, the React store or the Reactive store is not, will not be public yet. Only the framer overrides.
quotes.title: Framer Overrides and Developer Experience
quotes.context: Strategic thinking about which products to expose publicly. Testing new patterns (reactive stores) in a more contained environment (Framer-specific overrides) before releasing them broadly to the market.

quotes.text: By batching support and documentation work into specific periods, you create space for deeper, uninterrupted work on core product.
quotes.fullText: I wouldn't say overtime, but like I've done a lot of set of work so that I could have some weeks where I could focus more on we, this is something I'm gonna try and do, um, moving forward. I still, you know, have to do support on both, but trying to kind of do more of the, like the focused real work, the working, like in the business work, um, or on those anyway, um, more like have more focus time.
quotes.title: Post-MicroConf Reflections and Laravel Focus
quotes.context: Queen is deliberately creating focus time by batching other work (support, documentation) into specific periods. This allows deeper, uninterrupted work on core product development for her main ventures. It's about intentional rhythm, not just hustle.

quotes.text: After being super focused and getting everything done, my brain needs a week where it's not as focused and that's okay.
quotes.fullText: I kind of know that I could see it coming, like being so focused and getting so much done that there will be a week where like less stuff gets done and that's okay. Before, I would probably like be very, oh no, like now everything is down the dumps. I'm not as focused and it's been like two days. But now I know that's kind of the natural cycle.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen is normalizing post-intensity recovery as part of her working rhythm rather than seeing it as failure. This is a maturation in how she manages her energy.

quotes.text: I can give a task and see it not work out. Nobody's feelings are hurt. The work gets thrown out and you just ask again.
quotes.fullText: I feel like I can train on the AI a little bit. I can give a task and I can see it not working out. And nobody's feelings are hurt that their work is just thrown out the door and you can just ask it again. And I even had Claude help me with a task framework so that I can write better tasks.
quotes.title: AI Episode #2
quotes.context: Queen recognizing AI agents as low-stakes practice for a skill she needs: defining tasks clearly and accepting imperfect results. No human feelings at risk when you reject AI output, making it a safe training ground for delegation skills she'll need with human collaborators too.

quotes.text: The tech industry trained users to expect constant change, but customers actually want stability and proven longevity.
quotes.fullText: It's all about perception, you know? Users, I mean, it's this weird thing, right? Where our customers won't—I can't speak—they want a stable long-term product, right? Because they don't want something made yesterday that will go away. And they don't want two big changes because then they have to learn new things to change their workflows. Also, I guess it's the tech industry who's like trained people that if there aren't like many things changing, it means the product will like die tomorrow.
quotes.title: New Year Gratitude & Framing Perception
quotes.context: The fundamental gap between what customers want (stability, proven longevity, consistent interfaces) versus what the tech industry conditioned them to expect (constant visible change as a sign of vitality). Queen sees mini launches as a bridge.

quotes.text: Almost all the Webflow+Airtable people on LinkedIn had 'visual developer' as their title—they identify as developers, but their strength is the visual interface.
quotes.fullText: I did a search for Webflow and Airtable and no code on LinkedIn to see what people were saying. And when I looked at their profile, almost all of them had visual developer as their title. So they are kind of aware that their strength isn't—it's coming from the design side, but I also think it is in the way that they build things, they build it through a visual interface. So they call themselves developers and they use Webflow or other tools, but they make that distinction with visual.
quotes.title: Physical Kanban, Worker MVPs & Sitting Out Scaling Problems
quotes.context: Queen discovering the self-identification of her target audience through LinkedIn research. 'Visual developer' is the term they use—developer identity with visual tool specialization. This is the vocabulary for Galleon's marketing.

quotes.text: Knowledge work is gradually less healthy with age. Screen work compounds. It's not high-risk, but the cumulative impact adds up, especially over decades.
quotes.fullText: But like this like thing we've chosen to do as our life's work is not, yeah. Good for not the healthies profession out there. Absolutely not. And I think like less and less healthy, like when you were younger it was fine. Yeah. And I mean, it's also not the most hazardous job you could do, right? I mean, not like we die.
quotes.title: Flu, Morning Walks, and Learning Communities
quotes.context: Queen acknowledging the health toll of knowledge work. When you're young it's fine, but the impact compounds. It's not high-risk, but the sustained screen time adds up, especially over decades.

quotes.text: Galleon Gateway is an auth provider + data source connector + role-level security gateway for non-coders who don't understand security.
quotes.fullText: You sign up for Galleon Gateway, then you select whatever auth provider you have in your business. So that could be Outseta or Clerk or other types of services. And then you select your data source, which could be Airtable, Supabase, Notion, or a Google Sheet type thing. And then you can configure basically role level security to start with, but some kind of like authorization where you say, okay, people with this thing has access to these rows, or they only have access to these rows if their user ID can be found under the user id column. And what I'm basically trying to do is act as a proxy that handles auth verification and data access control.
quotes.title: Scattered After Focus & Gateway Vision
quotes.context: Queen articulating the core vision for Galleon Gateway. It's a security layer that abstracts away the complexity of row-level security implementations across different data sources and auth providers.

quotes.text: MCP servers offer flexible blueprint prompts instead of rigid hardcoded templates for account setup.
quotes.fullText: We've been looking at making blueprints, but we don't really have an import thing... when we get a remote MCP server going, we could have different kind of blueprint prompts... it's less rigid and also it's hard for us to just start your account with demo content.
quotes.title: Annoyed, Relieved & Shipping the Redesign
quotes.context: Queen seeing MCP servers as a more flexible alternative to hardcoded blueprints. Rather than predefined templates, prompts allow users to customize the setup interactively while the AI figures out the implementation.

quotes.text: I'm kind of betting against AI. I think people want to hear from that founder and hear their passion and their way of talking about it.
quotes.fullText: I feel like it's kind of like a little bit of a shift now where people kind of want that more, like we talked about last time, that I'm kind of betting against AI. Like I think people want to hear from that founder and like hear their passion and hear their way of talking about it. And also if you wanna reach developers that are not beginners, the founder is often the person to talk, because they have that expert knowledge.
quotes.title: Playful Ideas, Livestream Services & the SaaS Baby Book
quotes.context: Queen positioning her service against the AI content trend. For intermediate/advanced developers, the founder's expert knowledge and authentic voice is what resonates. AI can't replace the founder's passion.
